TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. In effect, it amends four Acts covering superannuation for Commonwealth sector employees, namely, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990, the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990 and the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988. The changes being made in this Bill do not represent any major new contributions for the reform of Commonwealth superannuation; rather, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said in his second reading speech, the Bill proposes some changes to bring the 1976 Commonwealth superannuation scheme into line with the occupational superannuation standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes some changes to streamline administration of the Acts and the schemes; removes some anomalies in the benefit provisions of the current legislation, thereby providing greater equity between members; and makes some drafting amendments to clarify the intention of the existing legislation. Most of the amendments are technical in nature. Most of them relate to the 1976 Commonwealth scheme, although, as I said, four separate Acts are involved.

Since the establishment of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, three superannuation schemes have been introduced for Federal public servants. The first scheme, introduced in 1922, is called the 1922 superannuation scheme. The scheme under the Superannuation Act 1976 is called the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, the CSS, and the scheme under the Superannuation Act 1990 which was legislated in this place last year is called the public sector superannuation scheme, the PSS.

The Bill, of course, relates just to superannuation provisions applying to Commonwealth public servants. As I said, because the matters are essentially technical in nature and minor, I do not propose to go into details. I understand that my colleague Senator Watson, who is following me in this debate, will be taking up certain issues that are particularly relevant to those schemes.

In view of the circumstances of the day, I will not detain the Senate very long in the debate on this Bill, other than to point out that we have just listened to a Budget presented by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) which, quite frankly, one could only describe as pathetic. It is a Budget which has nothing at all of hope in it for the Australian economy and nothing at all of hope in it for the million plus people in this country who are now on the scrap heap of unemployment. They have been looking for some hope, some guidance and some specific policy direction in this Budget to lead this nation out of this deep and protracted recession. It is the longest recession since the 1930 recession and the deepest recession that we have had in the past 60 years.
The relevance of the Budget that we have just heard to this present Bill is that one of the proposals in the Budget is the creation of a new compulsory levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Non-deductible.

—As my colleague says, a non-deductible levy to apply to employers who-regardless of their circumstances-do not meet the Government's fiat that there be a 5 per cent employer contribution for all superannuation schemes in the future. Far from encouraging work force growth -that is what people in this country want-this proposal within this Budget is designed, particularly through the superannuation provision, to put more and more people onto the scrap heap of unemployment and lost opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government will stand indicted on that matter for living memory. The loss of dignity and job security that this Government has wrought on the work force of Australia is the greatest possible indictment that one could make of any government. All businesses, but particularly small business, will be devastated by this Budget decision on superannuation. The decision defies economic logic: there is nothing in it which links the requirement for employers to pay this employer contribution to, if you like, increased production or productivity. It is just an additional cost on top of the already crippling cost burden that employers face.

The small business sector, in particular, has witnessed record growth in the level of bankruptcies in the past 12 months-and that has been a major contributor to the million plus people who are unemployed. That will continue to impact on the small business sector, firstly, because of a deal that was done behind closed doors between Bill Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the discredited former Treasurer, Paul Keating, and, latterly, because of the screws put on him last week by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It has nothing at all to do with providing the things that employees in this country want: job growth and job security.

Of course, extended coverage of superannuation is a very desirable objective. I think that that is an objective that all parties in this place share. But to try to force it on a work force and on the providers of work, employers, at a time of extreme recession is, in my view-and, obviously, in the view of the business community and most thinking people in this country-just sheer lunacy. To use the words of our colleague on the other side of the chamber, Senator Walsh, anyone who would perpetrate this on the Australian community at this time must be either a fool or a fraud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, the Senate is debating the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill, which is occasionally affectionately referred to as the SLAB Bill, is the annual omnibus Bill which amends the various pieces of legislation which collectively regulate the superannuation of the non-military employees of the Commonwealth public sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of public sector superannuation is not widely regarded as particularly scintillating, largely because the situations are so complex and often obscure. Yet, to the generally small number of people affected by the so-called technical amendments with which this Bill is replete, the issues are important because they directly affect their standard of living.

A number of superannuation schemes are operated by the Commonwealth. The Superannuation Act 1990 and regulations provide a comprehensive occupational superannuation scheme for Commonwealth Government employees, statutory officers and employees of statutory authorities to which the Act and regulations apply. This is known as the public sector scheme, or PSS. The former scheme-known as the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, or CSS-is regulated by the Superannuation Act 1976, is the largest of the Commonwealth schemes and is now closed.

The Superannuation Act 1922 provides the continuing authority for the payment of pensions to, or in respect of, persons who were pensioners on 30 June 1976 and also some others with deferred benefit entitlements. This is referred to in this legislation as the superseded Act. There are also separate superannuation arrangements in respect of some former expatriate employees in Papua New Guinea, politicians, judges and the Governor-General, as well as a variety of arrangements which apply to members of the defence forces.

The administration of these numerous arrangements is shared between the Minister for Finance and part of the Department of Finance; the Commissioner for Superannuation, who is the head of the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office; the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority; and the various boards of trustees attached to each scheme. The funds' management function is undertaken by Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd, although its statutory monopoly in this regard will terminate in 1995.

The Bill before the Senate today proposes 80 distinct amendments. Clearly, and perhaps fortunately, we do not have the time to consider each one separately-and I thank the departmental officers who provided a patient briefing to a member of my staff on all the issues.

The pieces of legislation to be amended are the superannuation Acts of 1976 and 1990, the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990 and the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988.

The main proposed amendments to the 1976 Act include transferring the leave without pay and preservation functions from the Minister to the Commonwealth Superannuation Board established under the Act; extending the powers of the Commissioner for Superannuation to allocate reversionary benefits; allowing persons who have not retired from the work force to postpone payment of age retirement benefits; extending the arrangements for persons transferring to a scheme run by their employer to include deferred benefits; ceasing the issue of benefit classification certificates so that members can make their choice between staying in the CSS scheme or transferring to the PSS scheme with some certainty as to their benefits, provided that no false information has been given by fund members; removing the potential for the double payment of benefits; allowing the board of trustees to decide the appropriate treatment of the tax liability which arises in respect of certain taxable contributions; and ceasing, from 1 July 2000, payment of lump sum benefits to those who have retired involuntarily whilst aged under 55. The duration of time between the passage of this legislation and its commencement is almost nine years. This is apparently considered to be the most politically prudent date from which to alter these arrangements.

The 1990 Act is to be amended in a variety of ways, including clarifying that certain former employees with entitlements under the 1976 scheme must rejoin the 1976 scheme before being able to exercise an option to transfer to the 1990 scheme; and providing financial and other arrangements under which members may transfer to separate schemes established by their employers.

In this regard I wish to raise the question of the rights of the employees of government business enterprises which are to be privatised. I have received representations from an employee of Australian Airlines and would like to quote from that letter as follows:

The recent Australian Airlines privatisation debate completely ignored the issue of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme entitlements accorded to the large number of CSS members within the airline. I joined the airline under conditions that included the promise of CSS entitlement and an indexed pension at retirement.
Generally, the Government has been scrupulous in protecting the rights of existing members to their own funds and, in general, superannuation arrangements in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Not for casual employees?
—No, that is right. Fund members are given the option of continuing with the status quo or electing to join a scheme with differing conditions applying.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it does not appear that the CSS members who are Australian Airline employees-and the letter estimates the number to be between 500 and 600-will be allowed to remain in the scheme, in contrast with other public sector employees. This is in spite of the fact that many have been contributors for over 20 years. Irrespective of the arguments relating to the privatisation of the airline, there is a genuine need to treat the employees in an equitable manner. Therefore, I ask Senator McMullan to inform the Senate of the arrangements which are to apply to these employees, who are currently unsure of their future entitlements.

Given the future privatisation program of the Government and the total privatisation program of the coalition, it seems very important to the Australian Democrats that the Government set a fair and equitable precedent for existing fund members. The Housing Loan Insurance Corporation is the most recent privatisation precedent and that is, without question, a total disaster. It may even have to be aborted due to the poor rating of the purchaser. I will be discussing the debacle surrounding that privatisation at a future date. But now I go back to the Bills.

The third piece of legislation to be amended is the Superannuation Benefits (Supervisory Mechanisms) Act 1990. A Commonwealth agency cannot establish a superannuation scheme without the approval of the Minister. This Act allows the Minister to determine guidelines, which are disallowable instruments, for the provision of superannuation benefits to persons employed by certain Commonwealth bodies. Compliance with these guidelines entitles the agency to establish a scheme and any departure from the guidelines must also be approved by the Minister.

The amendment in the Bill is to ensure that any amendments to multi-employer guideline determinations need not be reissued to an employer who is not affected by these changes. We do not oppose this change, as it should save both time and money by restricting the provision of information to those to whom it is relevant.

The other piece of legislation being addressed in this so-called SLAB Bill is the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988, which provides superannuation benefits for Commonwealth employees not covered by other arrangements. The Bill proposes amendments to the Act to provide that where a person covered by the Act joins the 1990 scheme, that is, the PSS scheme, the employer is to pay the benefit and any interest to the PSS scheme. This is a technical amendment only and is not opposed by the Australian Democrats.

Two other measures which I would like to raise at this point are the subjects of Democrats amendments to be moved in the committee stage of debate. The first is a fairly contentious matter, I expect. It concerns the rights of members of the 1976 and 1990 schemes. Currently, on the death of a fund member, certain reversionary benefits become payable to a spouse or other dependants. We believe the current definition of `spouse' is discriminatory against homosexual people living in bone fide de facto relationships. These fund members pay exactly the same contributions as heterosexual members, yet the homosexual members are not entitled to reversionary benefits in respect of their partners. Accordingly, I will circulate a series of amendments to the 1976 and 1990 superannuation Acts which propose to treat de facto homosexual couples identically with de facto heterosexual couples.

I know that this matter will raise genuine concerns, and I am certainly not putting it forward in a provocative way, particularly in view of the recent publicity on so-called outings. However, it is a matter of justice, and there is no doubt that the benefits available to homosexual superannuation fund members are arbitrarily lower than those available to comparable heterosexual members. I apologise to the Senate and to honourable senators for the short notice I have given of these amendments. However, the drafting is only just now being completed.

I take this opportunity to once again refer to the difficulties experienced in the drafting of Democrats and, I understand, Opposition amendments for various pieces of legislation. It is certainly not the fault of the Clerks concerned who, I believe, are applying almost superhuman efforts to cope with the workload that they are facing. I think the reality is that some action must be taken to provide some additional resources to that office, or we will find that the business of this Senate will grind to a halt. Already, we have another Bill-the Copyright Amendment Bill-which may have to have its committee stage of debate deferred because amendments are not yet completed. I reiterate that this is not a criticism or a complaint directed at the Clerks office, which is pursuing the work of drafting amendments; it is simply that the workload is too large and the resources are too small. I believe it is the Government's responsibility to take action to rectify these circumstances.

There is a second amendment that I wish to foreshadow at this stage. It is related to the question of bereavement payments available to members of the scheme under the 1922 Superannuation Act. Currently most, if not all, Commonwealth superannuation schemes provide special payments known as bereavement payments in the event of death of a fund member. The full rate of pension is payable for six fortnights after the time of death to assist with any additional costs which may arise and to postpone any administrative arrangements which must be made to alter the pension payment.

The second amendment proposes to extend to the 1922 scheme the same rights as those that are available to members of the 1976 and 1990 schemes and the new military superannuation scheme. In addition, age pensioners are entitled to this payment and they receive the added bonus of a tax exemption on the extra portion of the bereavement benefit. I hope that the Opposition will see its way clear to support this measure, as it indicated earlier this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating for the second time, and obviously not the last time this year, Bills relating to superannuation. The Budget proposals announced a few moments ago introduced significant cost imposts on business but, unfortunately, none of those changes heralded in the Budget do anything to improve the efficiency of the administration of superannuation funds, particularly for casual workers. The Senate might be aware of the number of notices of motion that I have put forward outlining the problems faced by casual workers in the erosion of their benefits as a result of tax and administrative charges. There is something fundamentally wrong with many of these schemes and the way in which they apportion cost to the detriment of the non-active or casual employees who have left that particular industry.

SPEECH.PARA: My Senate colleague Jim Short outlined the ambit of these Bills. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) in his second reading speech stated that the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 amends four superannuation Acts which relate to the provision of superannuation benefits for Commonwealth sector employees.

Basically the Bill does not address any new or major Government initiatives. Its intent is instead to bring the 1976 Commonwealth superannuation scheme into line with the occupational superannuation standards, to make some changes to streamline the administration of the Acts and the schemes, to remove some anomalies in the benefits provisions of the current legislation, thereby providing greater equity between members, and to make some drafting amendments to clarify the intention of the existing legislation.

I would also like to take this opportunity to call upon the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to audit and enforce more rigorously the compliance of those funds with the occupational superannuation standards. I think it is a travesty that that lack of compliance is currently under way. I call upon the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to put more resources into this area of audit.

I must also express some concern that the Acts when originally debated were not sufficiently well drafted as to be clear and free of anomalies. This has no doubt caused a great deal of extra work for those administering the Acts and has required the time of the Senate again today so that those deficiencies can be rectified. At least the Senate has sufficient time to address this Bill fully whereas the guillotine was applied to the debate in the House of Representatives. The imposition of the guillotine when this Bill passed through the House resulted in the Minister giving his second reading speech and no further debate being allowed before the Bill was passed. That sort of debate is really a denigration of democratic principles and accountability, and the sovereignty of parliament.

I wish to raise a couple of matters in relation to this Bill. The first is the proposed cessation of the cash-in-hand lump sum superannuation retirement benefit in the 1976 scheme from 1 July 1990. Whilst appreciating that this change has been made to bring the Commonwealth scheme into line with occupational superannuation standards, I deplore the general attitude of the Government with regard to lump superannuation arrangements. I mentioned this problem at great length when the Superannuation Bill 1990, which introduced a new Commonwealth superannuation scheme for most Commonwealth employees, was being debated in May last year.

The Government continues to be hypocritical. It introduced lump sum superannuation arrangements for its own employees but at the same time it promoted pension-type schemes for the private sector. More than three years ago, during extensive parliamentary debate on superannuation Bills, Ministers repeatedly expressed their disgust at double dipping, and rightly so. By double dipping, I am referring to the practice of lump sum payments being taken by retirees who spend their money and, at a later time, take a pension benefit from the Government. At the time, the social security review unit said that at least half of all the supportive benefits should emerge in pension form. I agree with that review unit: it is quite reasonable. But the Government has chosen another route, which is not correct. This is a major cause for concern and I would urge the Government to address this problem as soon as possible.

Whilst this Bill makes some alterations to simplify and streamline administration, it has not addressed one area of concern which I have raised on each occasion that I have spoken on superannuation. I am referring to the iniquitous tax on superannuation contributions. Entry into superannuation funds, in terms of payments coming from the employer, attracts a tax of 15 per cent. If this were changed and the income of the fund were taxed, additional funds would be released for investment, which this country desperately needs. It would also release thousands of people associated with the administration and collection of this money. Superannuation administration would be more cost efficient. The direct lowering of administration costs would assist those people who work in an industry on a casual or part time basis being deprived of the 3 per cent levy that is invested by the employers for their benefit, because it is eaten up in administration costs. This is absolutely atrocious. As a parliament we must devise a simple scheme to lower those high administration costs. One mechanism for doing that is to take away the 15 per cent tax on entry.

What I propose here is a mechanism not to reduce the total tax collections but to make sure that this process is administratively more cost effective and efficient. This arrangement would certainly produce a simpler and fairer scheme, thus making superannuation more attractive, which in turn would increase the level of savings. That is what superannuation is all about. It is not a golden nest egg to be attacked by governments in the form of increased levels of taxation.

One of the anomalies dealt with in this Bill concerns invalidity pensioners. Apparently, it has been possible for a few invalidity pensioners to receive benefits based on one salary but have the earnings test applied to a much lower salary. Clause 26 amends this, and thus the salary used for benefits is also to be used for the earnings test. However, the correction of this anomaly does not address the fact that invalidity rates for Commonwealth employees are presently five to 10 times those of the private sector. In May last year, I appealed to the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, to ensure that the Commonwealth employees scheme received further attention and revision such that it would reduce the invalidity rates of the current scheme from their unacceptably high level. Most people would perceive that working in the Public Service should not lead to such high invalidity rates-five times higher than those in the private sector. That is just unacceptable.

I see no problems with the technical aspects of this Bill provided, of course, that the matters raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills have been and will be dealt with. I am referring to subclause 2(4) of the Bill requiring the Minister's confirmation that the retrospective operation of the clause is beneficial to persons other than the Commonwealth; clause 59, which refers to retrospectivity of regulations; and clause 4, paragraph (e), defining a deferred annuity which the Committee would ordinarily regard as a Henry VIII clause. I hope Senator McMullan will confirm that in his response.

If the Australian Business magazine of 7 August is to be believed, it would appear that there are still several problems with the new superannuation system for public servants. The article reports that only 35 per cent of public servants have chosen to change from the old scheme to the new. If this is the case and the Bill does not remedy the disadvantage of the new system, the Government obviously needs to make further amendments.

At this stage I do not support the mechanisms put forward by the Australian Democrats. I fail to see why homosexual partners should have the same rights and entitlements as an ordinary spouse. This tends to have the effect not only of introducing a controversial issue but also of lowering the standard of the sanctity of marriage. If passed, this amendment would provide a degree of dignity to such groups which I believe is incompatible with the social attitudes and public morals of the vast majority of Australian citizens.

Given this very low level of movement from the old to the new scheme, I do not think it is incumbent upon oppositions to lift benefits to make them comparable when the Government is encouraging participants to move from one scheme to another and, at the same time, it is widely acknowledged that the 1922 scheme has certain benefits over and above the latter schemes. There is no great incentive-if they continue to build up those sorts of benefits in the old scheme-for people to transfer into the newer schemes.

The coalition does not oppose certain transfers of functions to the new Insurance and Superannuation Commission. However, being a Tasmanian, Mr Acting Deputy President, you would sympathise with my concerns. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there is no office of the ISC in Hobart. From the point of view of trustees, managers, employers, beneficiaries and participants in the scheme, the administration of funds will be all the more difficult because access to the ISC is to be through the Melbourne office.

I have had dozens of complaints of people being unable to access the Melbourne office on the telephone because the phone is always jammed; it is always engaged. I appeal to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer to ask the ISC to increase the number of lines because it is very difficult to get answers to problems when one is interstate and does not have access. There needs to be a 008 number readily accessible to the people in my State of Tasmania who do not have the availability of a local office. I appeal, firstly, in the short term, for improved telephone access and, secondly, for the establishment of an office. With the increasing importance of superannuation and because of what the Government intends to do by way of extending the Superannuation Act, it is vitally important that an office of the ISC be located in Tasmania in order to properly service the needs of all those concerned with superannuation in Tasmania. I have several other concerns but I will not take up the time of the Senate by raising them. I will put them forward at the relevant Estimates committee hearing.

Superannuation has become a hotchpotch of rules and regulations, far too complex for the average man in the street to comprehend. It was unfortunate that last year we passed a whole series of legislative changes that had a good intent so far as deductibility was concerned but certainly made the Act much more incomprehensible. I again call upon the Government to simplify the rebate or deductibility regime to ensure that there is a lot more certainty in the Act. On so many occasions I have appealed to the Government regarding the need for simplification. The complexity of so many of these changes, particularly in the superannuation area, is inconsistent with this notion of self-assessment.

I welcome the appointment of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, of which I am a member, and I look forward to its deliberations and recommendations. We have been given 17 different headings to address, including the possibilities for simplifying superannuation and the adequacy of prudential control arrangements applying to superannuation funds. It is my personal hope that this Committee will be able to formulate, based on the evidence from the numerous participants who will come before it in public hearings, a set of recommendations which when implemented will provide a future unchanging base on which the superannuation industry can operate with a higher level of assurance. The regular occurrence of amendment after amendment before this place has to be halted so that Australians can plan ahead for their retirement with a greater degree of certainty and surety than they have in the past eight years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the end of the debate we ranged widely on the issue of superannuation beyond the limited confines of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill. It is a very important issue, and I understand that people want to take the opportunity as it arises to make some general comments. I will respond only briefly to anything that was said in that part of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is fairly limited in its scope. The Acts that are amended by this Bill relate to the provision of superannuation benefits for Commonwealth sector employees. Even within that more limited confine the Bill does not contain any major initiatives. As was said in the second reading speech, it is proposing some changes to bring the 1976 scheme into line with the occupational superannuation standards, to streamline the administration, to remove some anomalies, and to make some drafting amendments for clarification. Most of the amendments are essentially technical in nature. Consequently, the financial impact of the amendments as a whole is minimal. Within that general framework let me deal with some of the questions that were asked of me and the amendments that are proposed and, briefly, some of the comments which were made.

Senator Spindler asked a specific question concerning the implications for employees of Australian Airlines of its forthcoming sale. As Senator Spindler and the Senate would know, Australian Airlines has had its own superannuation arrangements for a long time. Most of its employees would be covered by those arrangements but some employees remain covered by the Superannuation Act 1976.

When Australian Airlines is sold it will cease to be in the public sector. As such, while its employees in its own scheme will continue to be covered by that scheme-they will continue to be employees of Australian Airlines-those employees covered by the Superannuation Act 1976 will cease to be eligible employees for the purposes of that Act. Therefore, they would no longer be able to contribute to the CSS-the 1976 Commonwealth superannuation scheme. They will be able to preserve the stake that they built up in the scheme by leaving their stake in the CSS to accumulate until retirement. They will also be able to join the airline's scheme. That would create a situation in which at retirement they would receive an indexed CSS pension, a refund of their contributions to the CSS and benefits from the airline's scheme.

Furthermore, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has agreed that prior to the sale these CSS members will be offered the option of transferring to the airline's scheme with appropriate credit for past CSS membership. The transfer will be made on the same terms as earlier transfers from the CSS to the airline's scheme, and ample time will be allowed for individual decisions. The Commonwealth will provide funds to meet the cost of the past service credit. Such employees could also choose to take a cash payment of their own contributions to their CSS plus interest. However, this option would mean forgoing the employer financed benefit built up from their past CSS membership, and people will need to be conscious of that in making their choices. Obviously, redundancy benefits under the CSS will remain available to any CSS member who is made redundant before the sale is concluded. The Government shares Senator Spindler's concern about the positions of those employees who are affected, and processes are under way to ensure that a reasonable range of options is available.

I now turn to the specific amendments proposed by Senator Spindler. The first concerns the 1922 Act. Prior to my exposure to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and its various ramifications, I thought the only significance of 1922 was that it was the name of the committee that ran the Conservative Party in the UK. I find that we now have this extraordinary 1922 set of provisions with which we still have to deal, notwithstanding the fact that nobody can now join that scheme. It is a comment on the history, evolution and change of superannuation schemes that we had the 1922, the 1976 and the 1990 variations. We would hope that with the 1990 scheme being in place we can now return to a more stable period of superannuation arrangement for public sector employees.

The Government is opposed to the proposed amendment. There are concerns about cost. There are concerns that this would follow on from enhancements which have been made to the 1922 scheme, usually at no cost to members. Each of those arguments would therefore raise some questions on whether we ought to be proceeding in this way. However, I am particularly concerned for a third reason. The enhancements that were made to the 1976 Commonwealth superannuation scheme-that was essentially what we were dealing with in this matter and concerning the six fortnights reversionary pension-and other enhancements were paid for in full from savings arising from the tighter invalidity retirement procedures to apply to the 1976 scheme.

In other words, we had a symmetry in that package where some changes in tightening the 1976 scheme generated savings that funded the enhancements. There were no such savings generated within the 1922 scheme. We are moving from a scheme of proper symmetry to a scheme where we are simply saying to taxpayers, `Please fund an increased benefit to this group of people'. It is not such a terrible thing to be seeking extra benefits for any group of workers, and many of the people affected would be constituents of mine, but in terms of spending $8m of taxpayers' funds, it is not a provision that we are proposing to endorse because there are no such savings from the Superannuation Act 1922. That is why in 1990 the enhancement of a higher reversionary pension was not extended to pensioners under that Act. It was not a whim or malice; it was because the symmetry did not apply, and it does not apply now.

The pension schemes of the 1922 and 1976 Acts were different before the enhancements. It is not as if the two schemes were in all other respects equal and the enhancements made a distinction between them. They are in many ways different. Those differences will continue and that is no cause for particular concern, but we cannot just pick at random one element of the variation that does not benefit the people in the 1922 scheme and extend that to them without looking at all the other elements where they are advantaged over all the people in other schemes. It is neither a rational nor a balanced approach to government decision making and the Government will not support the proposed amendment.
We come then to the rather late in the day amendment concerning homosexual spouses. Senator Spindler and the Senate would be aware--

TALK.START.PARA: —De facto spouses.

—The Senate would be aware that this is not an issue that I find abhorrent in principle, but I have two concerns about it. One concern is that the issue has been raised very late in the day. I understand Senator Spindler's explanation that it was not an attempt to trick or trap but that he was caught up in the procedural processes of getting these matters before us and has been, perhaps, diverted by some other matters causing him some difficulty and with which we may all empathise. I was not au fait with all the details of the point Senator Watson raised about the problem with the Henry VIII clause and inappropriate delegation. I have had an opportunity to look only quickly at the point he raised. I understand it was a matter raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I note the general remarks made by Senator Watson about the administration of the ISC. I will take those remarks on board and draw them to the Minister's attention. —But not the process. The cart rolls on. We are continuing the process of looking at simplification in the area of superannuation.
