TALK.START.PARA: —This debate comes after a brief but, nevertheless, very useful inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which last week considered the Copyright Amendment Bill 1991 before the continuation of the second reading debate. It listened to the views of a number of witnesses representing publishers, authors, the industry in various forms, government officials, legal experts and others. The list of those represented appears at the appendix of the Senate Committee's report. Included amongst those I did not mention were the Australian Booksellers Association, the Australian Consumers Association, the Australian Record Industry Association and the Australian Copyright Council.

SPEECH.PARA: As you can see from that list, Mr Deputy President, there was broad range of submissions. Most of those organisations were represented before the Senate Committee and had a unique opportunity to debate the merits of this quite tricky piece of legislation. It is tricky in the sense that everyone in this place accepts the proprietary rights of the copyright holder and, on the other hand, the concern within the Australian public that books are not being made readily available at prices that are competitive with prices overseas. To some extent we have a conflict between the interests of consumers and the interests of copyright holders.

As I said, this was a unique opportunity for a Senate committee to consider these conflicting arguments and to help honourable senators formulate the positions that they will no doubt advance in the course of this second reading debate.

However, it did also mean that issues that had not previously been considered were raised. It seems to us that a few of those issues have resulted in the obvious need for further amendments-amendments that were not raised in the debate in the other place. Draftsmen have been working on that and, because of the short time frame, although we think that by the time the second reading debate is finished this evening the Opposition's amendments will be complete, they probably will not have received the degree of refinement that would be wise.

I understand from Senator Spindler that his draftspeople are taking a little longer and that his amendments are unlikely to be ready immediately after the completion of the second reading debate. We suggest that there be a short adjournment of the debate, perhaps until later this evening. It might turn out, from the Australian Democrats' point of view, that it might be better to proceed with the committee stage of the debate tomorrow. That is simply a fact of life arising from new matters coming out of the Committee's consideration of the Bill. I have no doubt that the Government will appreciate that reality and cooperate in that regard.

This Bill comes to us after eight long years and two major inquiries. As I said, there is no doubt that the Australian book buying public has long been disadvantaged in terms of price and availability by the importation provisions of the Copyright Act 1968. In the world book market Australia, along with New Zealand, South Africa and other smaller countries, is regarded as an appendage to the British market. Under the importation provisions, Australian booksellers can only import non-pirate books first published overseas from the holder of an Australian copyright, which is usually a British publisher.

Books which are first published overseas are sent to Australia by the British publishers through their own distributors. Because there is no incentive for the British publishers to publish the book in Australia promptly, this is at times a fairly leisurely process. Often, books published in the United States of America and then in Britain are not available in Australia until months or even years later. Sometimes they are never available in Australia. When books eventually arrive in our country, the prices charged are much higher than those charged in the United Kingdom. This happens not only in the case of an American book where the copyright for Australia has been sold to a British publisher, but also where a book has been published initially in the United Kingdom or any other foreign country. Of course, it is open to booksellers in Australia to flout the law and import books which they have obtained under the counter from an overseas wholesaler who is not the copyright holder. This is something that we do not condone, and want to avoid.

In 1983 the obviously unsatisfactory situation was eventually referred to the Copyright Law Review Committee, which reported some five years later in September 1988. The Copyright Law Review Committee's inquiry related to literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works, and subject matter other than works-namely, sound recordings, films, television and radio broadcasts and published editions of works. In other words, unlike this Bill, the CLRC inquiry was not just limited to books.

The Committee noted that copyright law provides protection and benefit for authors, although the principal beneficiaries are, of course, the multinational publishers. The CLRC was concerned about the absence of competition, inefficient practices and the overpricing of copyright material caused by the present restrictions. There was also concern that owners of copyright were being given a greater degree of protection than those dealing in other commodities. The CLRC concluded that importation of copyright articles should be allowed if the articles were not available in Australia within a reasonable time from when they were published overseas. Such a relaxation of the restrictions would benefit the Australian consumer because of decreased prices and increased availability of overseas publications.

Importers would be able to deal with several overseas suppliers and would be encouraged to keep their prices down, increase their variety, improve their importing and indenting services, and generally provide a much better service to the consumer. However, the Committee was not in favour of total repeal of the importation provisions. Book and record sellers and others interested in this issue generally welcomed the report and have advocated its implementation.

The Opposition was of the view that reform of the law in this area was essential, and a private member's Bill in the name of Mr Neil Brown, QC, was introduced in October 1989 in the other place which embodied the proposals of the Copyright Law Review Committee. The Bill subsequently lapsed. On 19 June 1989, one year after the CLRC report, the then Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, referred to the Prices Surveillance Authority the question of the price of books, including the effect of the Copyright Act on the price of books. The reference did not extend to other copyright articles.

In direct contrast to the CLRC report, the Prices Surveillance Authority report in December 1989 recommended the complete abolition of the copyright provisions which prevent the open flow of overseas-published books to Australia. The PSA concluded that, on the evidence, publishers engaged in international price discrimination and Australian consumers were suffering as a result. For instance, publishers who operated in the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia were able to set their prices lower in Canada than in the United Kingdom. They consequently set higher prices in Australia than they did in the UK. In Canada the price differential was 35c and 2.6 per cent below the UK price, whereas in Australia prices were $2.99 and 31.3 per cent-almost one-third-above the UK prices.

In the view of the PSA, the copyright provisions have resulted in a closed market and one which has relieved booksellers of the normal competitive pressures of responding to market demand. It believes that publishers have been hiding behind the provisions to continue to operate inefficiently. The report of the PSA was quite unequivocal in its view that the repeal of the copyright provisions would result in a fall in book prices. The PSA said that, although its recommendations related only to books, the copyright argument applied also to other areas, particularly sound recordings. It therefore asked for additional terms of reference.

The Bill currently before the chamber attempts to achieve a compromise between the recommendations of the PSA and the CLRC. In essence, it implements a modified version of the CLRC recommendations but it is only about books. It exempts the importation of non-pirate books from the operation of the importation provisions which provide that copyright is infringed by a person who imports an article for commercial purposes. The Bill in fact allows for parallel imports of books in three separate situations. The first situation-the so-called 30-day rule-concerns non-pirate books which are first published overseas after the commencement of the Bill. Such books must be published in Australia within 30 days of the original publication overseas in order to attract copyright provisions. The consequence of a book not being made available in Australia within the 30 days is that the copyright owner loses protection forever. This provision seeks to implement the PSA recommendation that new titles be published simultaneously overseas and in Australia in order to attract copyright protection. Under subsection 29 (1) of the Act, a work or book is published if reproductions or copies of the work have been supplied, whether by sale or otherwise, to the public.

The second situation concerns non-pirate books first published in Australia either before or after commencement of the Bill, or in a foreign country before commencement of the Bill. In relation to such books, if the copyright owner fails to supply sufficient copies for the Australian market copyright protection is lost temporarily. There are detailed conditions which must be fulfilled for parallel importation to take place in these circumstances: the importer must have placed a written order with the copyright owner which has not been withdrawn, the copyright owner must have failed to advise within seven days that the orders could not be filled, or the copyright owner must have failed to satisfy the order within 90 days after the order had been placed. Protection can be restored once the copyright owner resupplies the market. The third situation is that a single copy of a non-pirate book may be imported to fill a customer's written order for a single copy of a book.

The Opposition takes the view that this Bill does not go far enough. Whilst the Government has chosen to focus on the availability of books to Australian consumers, the Opposition is also concerned about the fact that, as the PSA found, Australians are paying too much for books. In other words, we recognise that price is as much an issue as availability. We support the total deregulation approach as advocated by the PSA. The Opposition's view is that Australia should not shirk from having the first open market for books in the English speaking world. I will be moving a second reading amendment which reflects our support for that position. I also foreshadow that in the Committee of the Whole I will be moving amendments to the Bill to extend its operation to other copyright articles in line with the report of the CLRC.

Whilst the Government has indicated that it intends to propose further legislation in relation to other copyright articles, the Opposition is anxious to accelerate the process of reform, given, as I said, that it has already taken eight years to reach this stage of proposed legislation in relation to books. This extension does not include computer software in view of the current inquiry by the PSA in this area.

The Opposition will also be seeking an amendment to introduce an exemption for textbooks so that copyright protection will be retained in the case of overseas-published textbooks, even when they are not published in Australia within 30 days of their first publication overseas. This is a result of our concern that the Bill could have adverse consequences on the supply of textbooks to Australian students. Our amendments will allow time for Australian adaptations to be prepared. Also, as the PSA pointed out in its report, its critical comments relating to price and availability of books do not generally apply in relation to the price and availability of textbooks.

Other Opposition amendments seek to allow time for industry adjustment to the new legislation by extending the commencement date so that it is three months after the date of the royal assent and to introduce a constructive knowledge requirement to subsections relating to infringement by importation for commercial purposes to reflect the fact that constructive knowledge is specified in section 132 of the Act dealing with criminal offences.

As a result-and, as I indicated a moment ago, as a result of the productive examination of the Bill by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee-the Opposition will be pursuing two further amendments. The first relates to the single copy exemption under which a single copy of a book may be imported to fill the written order of a customer. It is a simple commercial reality that many customers expect to be able to place such orders by telephone, and our amendment will provide for that. We do not see any particular reason why it should have to be in written form in light of today's technology.

Under the second new amendment proposed by the Opposition, booksellers would be able to import a specific number of books without infringing copyright in order to fill an order by a library for a number of books. The reason for this amendment is that Australian booksellers, under the current legislation, must treat libraries as any other customer and can import only a single copy of a book for them. Libraries have therefore formed the practice of ordering directly from large overseas suppliers. The Opposition's proposed amendment will allow libraries to order books from Australian booksellers rather than have them go offshore, and will therefore provide a much needed boost for our local trade in the current difficult economic climate. I hope that these two amendments will receive Government support. The short adjournment that I mentioned a moment ago might facilitate the Government's consideration of the obvious merit of these amendments.

Another issue which was discussed during the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee hearing was whether, if special protection were given to Australian authors, Australia would be in breach of the principle of the equal treatment of nationals contained in article 5 of the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works. Under article 5, works that originate in the country of another member state are to receive the same treatment that Australia accords to works of its own nationals. It is the nationality of the author, not the place of publication, which determines the application of article 5.

It is important to bear this in mind when considering the Government's Bill as it selects the place of publication as the criterion for invoking the 30-day permanent loss of copyright rule. It is arguable that the Bill constitutes a de facto discrimination against foreign authors as the 30-day rule in the vast majority of cases would apply to foreign authors.

In its submission to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, the Law Council of Australia stated its views that the enactment of this Bill would place Australia in contravention of its international obligations under the Berne Convention. The departmental officer present at the hearing undertook, I think it is fair to say, to make available to the Committee the conflicting advice to the Minister; perhaps it is fairer to say that he sought to refer that back to the Minister to see whether the Minister would make available to the Committee the conflicting advice that he had received from his officials. The Committee has not received that advice, and we do not know the reconsidered view of the Government on this matter.

However, as the view of the Law Council obviously should not be taken lightly-and no-one would be wishing to pass legislation in breach of Australia's obligations under international treaties to which it has become a party-we would expect during this debate to hear in some detail from the Minister as to why presumably he disagrees with the opinion given by the Law Council.

Other international considerations are also relevant. The United States pushed for trade-related aspects of international property rights-TRAIPS-to be on the negotiating agenda for the Uruguay Round in order to produce a uniform regime for the protection of intellectual property on a multilateral basis. The primary object of such negotiations is to address counterfeiting and piracy problems.

In the copyright area, the Australian delegation has argued that existing international conventions, such as the Berne Convention, are sufficient to meet the GATT principles of national treatment, non-discrimination and transparency. In the TRAIPS negotiations, Australia has focused on the need to improve multilateral enforcement and dispute resolution procedures. The US has specifically pushed for raising the level of protection offered by importation provisions. The importation provisions offer a means of controlling piracy and counterfeiting. It is arguable that to remove them altogether, as recommended by the PSA, prior to any outcome of the TRAIPS negotiations being obtained, would be imprudent. We look forward to the Government's considered view on that issue as well during the debate. Whilst the Opposition prefers an open market approach, as exemplified by the Prices Surveillance Authority, we recognise that there may be international impediments which would need to be dealt with first.

The second reading amendment which I will move calls on the Government to pursue, in the GATT Uruguay Round, the promotion of a uniform and universal regime for the protection of and trade in intellectual property rights. Further, it calls upon the Government to seek clarification of and, if necessary, amendment to the Berne Convention and the Universal Copyright Convention with respect to the application or otherwise of the provisions of those conventions to trade and distribution in intellectual property rights. In other words, whilst we advocate an open market-that is our preference; it is the direction that we believe is in the best interests of the Australian people and we would like to see it in legislative form-we recognise that the issue of the potential breach of these international conventions must be removed first, and that any conflicting provision contained in the Copyright Act must also be removed. Our second reading amendment therefore reflects that concern in the course of seeking the implementation of our preferred position, and that is, an open market for books in this country. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the anti-competitive protection that the importation provisions of the Copyright Act 1968 give to the trade and distribution of copyright articles should be removed by the repeal of those provisions and, to this end, calls upon the Government to:

(a) pursue in the international negotiations by Contracting Parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations the promotion of a uniform and universal regime for the protection of, and trade in, intellectual property rights; and

(b) seek clarification of and, if necessary, amendment to the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works and the Universal Copyright Convention with respect to the application or otherwise of the provisions of those conventions to trade and distribution in intellectual property rights''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Copyright Amendment Bill is to enable unrestricted commercial importation of non-pirate copies of books, other than those first published in Australia or first published simultaneously in Australia and overseas. Secondly, it seeks to suspend a copyright owner's control over importation of non-pirate copies of books first published in Australia or first published simultaneously in Australia and overseas, when supply becomes unavailable for more than 90 days. Finally, it will allow the importation of a non-pirate copy of a book at any time to fill a documented order from a customer for his or her non-commercial use. In terms of the financial impact, it is claimed-and certainly it is hoped by the whole community-that the changes are likely to lead to some reductions in prices of books supplied to Australian consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, the Australian Copyright Act, largely as a hangover from colonial days, allows British publishers to force Australian bookshops to buy only through their local subsidiaries or agents and they can run their Australian sales on the principle of what the market will bear. Pricing policy and supply are effectively controlled from Britain by virtue of the monopoly conditions created by the Copyright Act. From the consumer's point of view, the problems are long delays in obtaining some books, inaccessibility of others and high prices overall. Some booksellers, we are informed, covertly import books direct from America in contravention of the copyright law, but book prices have escalated rapidly in recent years and at higher rates than increases in the CPI.

Two reports have been published in recent years which proposed changes aimed at improving the flow to Australia of books published overseas and breaking the effective monopoly that British publishers have over the rights to many Australian books. The 1988 recommendation of the Copyright Law Review Committee report would allow any book not published in Australia within 90 days of its publication elsewhere in the world to be legally imported. In other words, it is a relaxation rather than a repeal of the current import provisions. In particular, this approach retains the concept of territorial divisibility of copyright.

The more recently released Prices Surveillance Authority report proposes deregulation of the imported book market with a 10-year protection period for Australian writers, if this proves legally possible, and there would be some doubt about that. The adoption of these recommendations would make Australia the first open market for books in the English-speaking world. The economics-oriented Prices Surveillance Authority concentrated on economic considerations, but obviously there are legal and cultural aspects to this issue as well.

It is for this reason that the Australian Democrats prefer the approach taken in this Bill on the basis of the Committee recommendations. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Bill, but we will not be supporting the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition. The reason for that is that while we believe consumers need a better go, the free-for-all that is envisaged by the second reading amendment would not be in the interests of Australia's cultural and social fabric. The clarification and, if necessary, amendment of the Berne Convention that is mentioned in the second part of the second reading amendment does not cure that defect.

In accepting the basic thrust of the Bill, the Democrats recognise that there are some concerns and some improvements which can be made. They lie in the area of the 30-day rule. We recognise that it is possible that delays may occur which are totally beyond the control of the person or organisation concerned. We believe that there should be exceptions created for such situations.

The other amendment refers to adaptations. Again, our approach in this area is likely to differ slightly from that of the Opposition. I would prefer, at this stage, to leave until the committee stage the debate on the details of our amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1991, I think it is reasonable to look at the history of how we have reached this particular position and to realise the length of time taken and the dalliance that has occurred in finally being presented with legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Copyright law in this country is governed by the Copyright Act 1968. This Act conferred considerable monopoly upon British publishers and their Australian subsidiaries. In spite of substantial evidence to this effect, it was not until 1983 that the Copyright Law Review Committee was given the task of examining the provisions of the Act. The Committee reported in September 1988 and, to my mind, in a rather unsatisfactory fashion. Its recommendations could not really be described as robust.

The reason for this is partly the unfortunate inherent premise that copyright law should act as some form of industry protection, if not for publishers and distributors, then for authors. It was implicit in the recommendations of the Committee that the repeal of the importation sections of the Copyright Act would have a detrimental effect on the subsidisation of local authors. The Committee did not supply much evidence on the question of overcharging in Australia as a result of the Copyright Act.

In June 1989, the Prices Surveillance Authority was charged with the task of considering an extensive economic analysis of the issues. It was not until December 1990 that the Prices Surveillance Authority handed down the final report of its investigation and that there were moves to introduce the legislation that we have before us today. As stated by the Prices Surveillance Authority:

The basic thrust of the Authority's proposals is to introduce more competition into the book trade, benefits to cost and allocative efficiencies and lower prices. Whenever a review of this kind is undertaken, the scaremongers always seem to come out of the woodwork.

It is interesting to look at some of the predictions that have been made. There were predictions that there would be a reduction in the stockholding in Australia by publishers and distributors; that there would be a decline in the availability of books to the Australian market; that there would be a decline in advertising and promotion by publishers; that the swallowing of independent Australian publishers by multinationals would take place; that the closure of small and, especially, country book stores would take place; and that the most dire consequences for the integrity of Australian authors would be a final result.

I admit that I am not one who has greatly admired the work of the Prices Surveillance Authority, but I commend the Authority on the way in which it resisted these prophecies and was prepared to see at least some deregulation of the book industry.

The Bill could be described perhaps as being more notable for what it does not achieve than for any impact it might have upon the market for books published overseas and sold in Australia. In spite of a formidable report of the Prices Surveillance Authority into sound recordings, and the Government's agreement in principle to legislate in this area, it remains as a conspicuous absence from this Bill. Considering the Government has, indeed, agreed in principle to follow the PSA's recommendations, and the simple comparative ease of drafting that could have taken place in accommodating sound recordings in this Bill as well, there was an opportunity for the Government to demonstrate legislative efficiency and deal with both items in the single Bill and, one could dare say, see some productivity in the way in which the Government handles its business.

In a Sydney Morning Herald article of 15 August 1991, Professor Fels presented a good case for reform. He indicated, in simple terms, that Australians have paid excessive prices for records for many years owing to the import restrictions. Currently, multinational companies monopolise the importation of records to Australia and record companies cannot import, or threaten to import, the same records from overseas, even though the overseas prices are significantly lower.

In a comment more akin to perhaps Milton Friedman or Adam Smith than any Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority, Professor Fels made the statement that competition is the only lasting way to achieve price restraint. For people like me, who value the role of the market, the statement is music to the ears. Indeed, one could say that it gave some respectability to the Authority and perhaps hope for the new appointment which Professor Fels has taken.

The opposition to the proposal that there should be deregulation of the music industry as well comes from a well-known rock star, one Peter Garrett, who has been known to show an interest in this place. Peter Garrett's suggestion was that there should be an enforced price freeze on all major record companies. Professor Fels quite rightly pointed out that not only was such a proposal likely to be a breach of the Trade Practices Act but also it was, of course, a highly undesirable proposition in itself.

The record industry and the publishing industry often claim that they are some sort of bastion of free enterprise. Unfortunately, the truth is that they hide behind a monopoly wall which prohibits imports and a copyright wall which restricts trade far more than any tariff ever did. Peter Garrett, when he ran for this place, ran on the basis that he had a social conscience and that he was interested in a system of social justice. It is perhaps timely to remind him that the system which he defends is in fact impacting upon those who can least afford to pay for the product which he makes. The needy simply cannot afford to pay for Mr Garrett's products owing to the system which he is advocating ought to remain in place.

In that context it is worth while looking at an example, and a good example would be Peter Garrett's own recording on CD of Blue Sky Mining. It is the Garrett supported system which ensures that that CD sells in New Zealand for $4 less than it does in Australia, while those in the United States can purchase the product for $10 less than we can in Australia. Price differentials for cassettes are in the vicinity of $5 and $9 respectively.

I also make mention of a very worthwhile article in the Australian of 19 December 1990, written by Paddy McGuinness. He pointed out that when it comes to the music industry, the consumers of pop music, who are predominantly young and low income earners, are being mercilessly ripped off. Mr McGuinness went on to say and again it is worth placing on the record:

Not only has the recorded music industry abused its control over imports to rip off consumers, it has also used it as a form of market power over distributors and retailers by using its powers to refuse supply as a means of debt collection, effectively appointing itself judge in its own cause.

Similarly, Professor Fels is spot on when he says that the theory that import monopolies will help exports and high Australian prices will boost overseas sales has no place in modern Australia. This has been accepted in the tariff debate and it should be the case in relation to non-tariff barriers.

I move to the details of the Bill before us today. This Bill implements recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee's report of 1988 which recommended that the importation of an overseas published book should be deregulated only in the case of a copyright owner failing to make that book available after a reasonable time. Senator Hill outlined the very specific proposals when he spoke earlier.

The Bill provides that the copyright owner will retain exclusive distribution rights over any books first published in Australia as well as those first published overseas but then published in Australia within 30 days. However, booksellers will be able to import directly books for commercial distribution where the copyright owner cannot supply those titles within 90 days of a written order. Parallel imports can continue until such time as the copyright owner fulfils any outstanding orders.

Although the Bill may make available in Australia works published overseas much sooner, there is likely to be little effect on book prices in Australia per se. Exclusive distribution rights organised amongst British and American publishers are assured provided they make timely distributions of books to Australia. It is noteworthy that American publishers frequently sell the British rights to British publishers and that Australia and other smaller countries are added as appendages to those rights. British publishers can then price discriminate between different countries because the ban on parallel imports prevents international arbitrage on the part of booksellers.

Australians have a high demand for books-a demand which remains high irrespective of price. This is evidenced by the fact that we purchase more books per capita than any other country in the world. This allows British publishers to charge much higher prices for books in Australia than they do elsewhere without adversely affecting their total unit sales. Due to the provisions of the Copyright Act, there is little incentive for British publishers to make books available for the Australian market promptly at competitive prices. The net result is overpriced books arriving on Australian shores months, if not years, after the same books are made available in the United States. Evidence suggests that there is also collusion between British publishers to set roughly equivalent prices for books which are close substitutes for one another.

By adopting the recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee, the Government has ignored the criticisms levelled at that report by the Prices Surveillance Authority. Readers have lost out on the benefit of protected Australian publishers and authors. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), in his second reading speech, claimed that consumers would suffer from the decline in distinctly Australian literature in a fully deregulated import market. By the erection of protective walls around the local publishing industry, the Government considers that it has the right to establish itself as the guardian of our literary tastes, irrespective of how the market may express itself and its taste for the published article. The irony of this call for protection by the taxpayer-subsidised literary elite-and, for a large part, the left wing-is that all their efforts are ultimately directed to the preservation of British and American monopoly privileges in the publishing industry.

However, I may not go quite as far as some in discussing the motives for this legislation. At the time when this Bill was first mooted early last year, it was suggested that the Government was attempting to appease the local industry in the run-up to the last Federal election. It was stated in an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 January 1990 that plainly Mr Bowen's compromise reform is designed to shut up the authors and publishers in the period before the election. If it is the wish of the Government to subsidise marginal Australian authors, the conferral of monopoly rights on foreign publishers in the hope that some of those profits will benefit Australian literature is perhaps the most inefficient way of doing so. It would be more efficient to provide direct subsidies to authors than to use this convoluted mechanism.

As we speak of the need for tax reform, it is worth while considering that higher book prices have resulted from the provisions of the Copyright Act and they have, in fact, acted as a tax on the consumption of literature to the detriment of readers and authors alike. The concern has been expressed that there may be a possibility that overseas editions of works by Australian authors may be remaindered and then dumped on the Australian market. It is unlikely that this would be covered by anti-dumping legislation as it could not be said to result in material injury to the particular industry. Any legitimate practice that would increase the exposure of Australian authors at no cost whatsoever should be genuinely encouraged, not condemned. If such a matter were of genuine concern, the issue could properly be dealt with in the contractual relationship between authors and their publishers.

The Bill will place considerable administrative costs upon importers. Importers will first have to establish a lack of availability of each title by placing a written order with the Australian copyright owner, who is allowed 90 days to fill that order. Should the copyright owner fail to fill the order, the importer will then face further costs as orders for imports will have been replaced by those with another publisher before being granted exemption from copyright infringement. The copyright owner may later be able to reassert his monopoly rights simply by supplying the market at a later date. It is noteworthy that many readers purchase their books directly from overseas for the simple reason that, in spite of shipping costs, it is both cheaper and quicker to import from an overseas supplier than to pay monopoly prices in Australia.

The discussion of copyright law brings into serious and fundamental question the matter of precisely what the notion of a copyright is supposed to achieve. I now believe that our perception of copyright is still evolving. The Prices Surveillance Authority reminds us that copyright is not an absolute property or moral right but exists for reasons of public policy. It is with this in mind, together with the need to move towards freer trade and open markets, that we should motivate our attitude towards copyright law and, indeed, see that it is in line with what is developed as a bipartisan policy in many respects to the need to reduce tariffs. On this side of the chamber, we have a more specific and honest attitude to the reduction of tariffs. Our attitude to this degree of protectionism for the publishing industry is in line with that philosophy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly in the second reading debate on the Copyright Amendment Bill. I do so as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which had this Bill referred to it for consideration. Last Monday week, we conducted a five-hour hearing when a number of organisations came before the Committee to give evidence. Of course, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and officers from the Attorney-General's Department were present, as were representatives from the Australian Booksellers Association, the Australian Copyright Council, the Association of American Publishers, the Australian Book Publishers Association, the Australian Society of Authors and the Prices Surveillance Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the representatives present, other than those from the Prices Surveillance Authority, by and large supported the Government's proposal, albeit somewhat reluctantly, to say the least. It is quite clear that only public pressure has made a number of these organisations willing to support the Government's Bill; if they had their way, they would have left the position exactly as it was.

The Prices Surveillance Authority stuck to its original proposition and answered quite forthrightly the questions from the Committee about why it believed its report still stood. I must say that, after the five-hour hearing, I still believe that the thrust of the Prices Surveillance Authority is essentially correct in what it is trying to achieve and how it should be achieved.

The major area of concern for Australians was the impact of the legislation on Australian authors who have signed arrangements to have books published in Australia, and who also have had those same books published overseas by the same publishing company, or under licence to another publishing company. What would happen to their incomes if those books were imported into Australia under some arrangement? There were some rather florid or exaggerated claims about the impact of book remainders overseas on Australian authors. This is very hard to predict because it is all a subjective judgment about what may happen if the present law is changed.

The Government's proposal is for 30-days grace for Australian publishers to publish in Australia, otherwise people would be allowed to import books. But it will be noticed that, by and large, that rule is more like a 90-day arrangement by the time people put in their notice about the response from the publishing company. So we are really talking about more of a three-month arrangement. It was not clear to me that even those 90 days would be effective. It seemed to me that the bureaucratic arrangements could mean that even the 90 days could be strung out. I cannot be sure of that because I do not know the actual details of how importing works-whether books are coming in by plane or ship, the notification given by the importing booksellers and so on.

What seemed to be very clear is that the major concern of Australian authors about the protection of their incomes has been somewhat exaggerated. The Australian Book Publishers Association said that the industry is worth just over $1 billion a year in sales in Australia. It said that, according to its estimation, of that $1 billion about 50 per cent-or $500m-comes from the sale of books which have Australian authors. But of that $500m, around $400m comes from Australian authors publishing books in Australia which are not sold overseas-books that are peculiar to the Australian market. The example given at the hearing was Max Walker, who writes books containing humorous tales about cricket. These are very popular in Australia but, clearly, are not published overseas because there is no real market overseas for a Max Walker, who is almost an Australian living legend or a living treasure in sporting and cultural terms.

The part of the market that we are dealing with-where Australian authors sell books in Australia that are published in Australia and also overseas-as estimated by the Australian Book Publishers Association, amounts to about $100m. In other words, only about 10 per cent of the Australian book market involves Australian authors who publish in Australia through an arrangement with a publisher, and who also are well known enough in the world to be able to get contracts to sell those books overseas-to have them published and printed overseas and to get some return from overseas.

We ought to keep those figures in mind. We may be trying to carry through arrangements here that protect people who do not need protection, in a sense. We do not need to protect Max Walker's market. We do not need to protect people publishing books on aspects of Australia that are not published overseas-that is, around $400m of the $500m market. Obviously, the books of other authors published overseas are imported into Australia. I cannot see why we should provide special protection to enable foreign authors to jack up prices in Australia through their book publishers. It seems to me that that is a matter they should take up with their own companies. They are probably doing very well out of it.

There is no doubt that the present system restricts the access of the Australian consumer to the wider range of books that should be available in a modern society such as ours. I think any of us who have had the good fortune to travel overseas and to go into any reasonable bookshop in London, New York, Washington, San Francisco or Los Angeles will have found a much greater range of books in particular areas than we have in Australia. For example, history is one of my personal interests and I always find that in bookshops in, say, London or Washington-when I have the opportunity to visit them-the reference sections are much bigger and the range of books is astonishing compared to what is available in Australia. There is no doubt that the present system discourages publishers from taking the trouble to allow those books to be imported and I think the Australian consumer is being affected.

In this Parliament we always talk about human rights and political freedoms and I would have thought that access to books and ideas is a very basic freedom that this country should nurture, demand and protect in absolute terms. One way that any society can control or curtail ideas is to limit the circulation of books. Anyone who has visited countries with authoritarian regimes will note that the free distribution and circulation of books is always more restricted than in those countries that have democracies. Because of commercial arrangements, we have an unnecessarily restricted system of book distribution in Australia-a system that a democracy cannot afford to have.

In making those remarks, I do not want to see Australian authors penalised here by selling overseas and facing unfair competition from people who may try to get around the copyright arrangements. I believe that it is possible, even without the so-called 30-day limit, to allow the importation of books by Australian authors which are printed in overseas countries so long as we have a customs regime that ensures that when the books come through Customs the royalty rate paid in Australia on the same books will be placed on the books being imported-whether it is the mechanical copyright or any other copyright or commercial arrangement. I have not had a chance to discuss this with officials in the Australian Customs Service, but I am told unofficially that it is not impossible for such a system to work. In effect, the rate paid on imported books could be topped up and they could not be distributed in a way that gets around copyright.

I think many of the fears raised by the industry claiming that if we change anything in this area we are going to allow pirated books in-books without copyright-to wreck the Australian market are greatly exaggerated. Of course, there will always be some pirated books coming in. Some may get through Customs with an Australian returning from overseas with a suitcase full of books, but a suitcase full of books is not going wreck the book market in Australia for major publishers.

After hearing this evidence, I have come to the view that even the 30-day limit may not be necessary. I notice that in the legislation a three-year review period is proposed. That is clearly necessary because I suspect-and I hope I am proven wrong-that even this present Bill, which is a major step forward, in practice may not see the reduction in book prices that Australian consumers want and that the PSA says we should have, and would still see the restriction on access by Australians to the wider range of books that are available in other Western and comparable countries.

While in the Copyright Amendment Bill we are dealing with books, the Government has before it the whole question of copyright as it concerns importations in the area of records, compact discs and tapes. In my view, the book publishing industry has been much more flexible and realistic about accepting these changes than the Australian Record Industry Association, which has been conducting what I can only call a wicked campaign of misinformation about what would happen if changes to parallel imports were allowed in the record industry, which in my view has been putting forward some demonstrably false claims.

I understand that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats will be moving amendments in the committee stage of the debate tomorrow. I have not seen those amendments yet. I understand that the Opposition amendments are similar to, if not the same as, those it moved in the House of Representatives. I am certainly interested to see what the Democrats put forward.

I say to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) that, if those amendments enable us to ensure that books can be imported into this country with no risk to Australian authors' copyright and incomes being affected, and if at the same time we can ensure that there is a wider range of books available and more competition in the book market, it is in accordance with this Government's micro-economic reform policies that those amendments be looked at. I therefore encourage the Minister to look at those amendments when they are circulated. I look forward to hearing the debate in the committee stage. I hope that some of my fears about this Bill not going far enough to allow effective competition will be proved wrong; however, I suspect they are right. Certainly the review process will be needed.

I suggest to the Minister that the three-year review process is too far away. Maybe within 18 months to two years we could get a pretty good grip on what is happening if this Bill is carried as is, or even with the amendments proposed. Any government's first priority should be to ensure that the Australian public has access to the widest range of books, because it is in books that there are ideas that overwhelmingly improve the cultural, social and political life of a community. It is ideas that make a democracy vibrant, and books are one of the major ways to spread those ideas. Any government must ensure that there is the widest opportunity for books to be available at reasonable prices to the Australian people.
