TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate on the important Copyright Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill is the Government's response to the widespread complaints throughout the Australian community that consumers have a right to access, as Senator Schacht so eloquently put it, the widest range of world literature, covering matters of important endeavours of the human mind and spirit, and works published for the enjoyment and entertainment of those who read them-not that those are necessarily mutually exclusive categories. Nevertheless, there is a whole range of material available in the form of books published overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a general understanding in the Australian community that we have had our access to that wonderful world restricted so that the availability of imported books has been less than it ought to be, and that this is because of the right of copyright owners to control the commercial importation of those books. There is also the question of whether prices have been inflated as a result of this control.

For my own part-and I think in harmony with much of the sentiment that has been expressed in the chamber-the question of the effect that the legislation before us will have on prices is perhaps more problematic than the effect that we hope to see in relation to availability. Most Australians who have an interest in reading would demand that the question of access to and availability of books be remedied by this Bill, and would feel that, if prices can be brought down, for example, through the availability of paperbacks, that will be a good thing too. Perhaps once again, to take up some of Senator Schacht's themes, it is the cultural impact of having access to the world of books that is so important for our development as a democratic society and a literate society. This proposal by the Government certainly provides a remedy to the perceived evil that I have outlined.

It is true that the Prices Surveillance Authority put forward what for many was a very attractive proposal; that cannot be denied. It recommended the total repeal of the copyright owners' right of control over the importation of books, with two exceptions, namely, Australian authored books published separately in Australia and pirated copies. As one would expect, many consumer groups, media commentators and booksellers supported this proposal most vehemently. However, some authors and publishers and even other booksellers put up an argument that the wholesale repeal of copyright owners' control over imports would seriously damage authors' incomes and Australian publishers' viability. This particular plea was listened to by the Government. The Government concluded that complete repeal of the importation provisions would pose too great a risk to Australian literature in general and to Australian authors and Australian publishers in particular. Therefore we looked for a solution short of complete repeal.

We believe that the reforms are well understood by those who attended the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. They are quite clearly well understood by all contributors to the debate this afternoon, and I do not feel any compulsion to go into great detail in relation to those reforms.

Basically, if the Australian copyright holder of a new overseas title wishes to maintain his or her exclusive right to supply the Australian market, he or she will be required to publish simultaneously in Australia and to maintain adequate stocks of copies, including paperbacks. Otherwise, there will be an open market for the book, either generally after 30 days from overseas publication-if there is no publication in Australia within that time-or for those booksellers whose orders the copyright owner has been unable to fill for more than 90 days, until supply from that source is restored. We believe that this requirement meets the legitimate needs of publishers, booksellers and the readers of books in Australia. This will be very important for the cultural and democratic reasons which have been so well outlined by speakers, particularly Senator Schacht, this afternoon.

It is proposed that, after three years from commencement of the provisions of this Bill, an appropriate reference will be given to the Prices Surveillance Authority to determine the impact of the amendments on book prices, which is certainly one of the original concerns underlying the Government's proposals in this area. But this must not be highlighted and given overwhelming weight for perhaps being the prime motivation of the Government in putting forward this proposal. I believe that lies more in the question of accessibility to world literature in its various forms.

I understand that Senator Hill raised some matters during the second reading contribution that he made as Leader of the Opposition in this chamber. I will comment firstly on whether this Bill is consistent with the question of Australia's compliance with the Berne Convention. Senator Hill may know-and I think officers indicated at the meeting of the Committee-that when the idea emerged of limiting control over parallel imports to books first published in Australia, regardless of the author's nationality, the Office of International Law was consulted and it advised that to do so would be consistent with our Berne obligations.

When the draft Bill was first published for public exposure, commentary and consultation, the Intellectual Property Law Committee addressed the question of its conformity with Berne and concluded that there was no problem. That was the initial reaction of the Committee. Therefore, the submission that Senator Hill adverted to at the Committee hearings was certainly a complete surprise to us and to the officers. I understood that the officer indicated to Senator Hill that he would be placing the matter before me.

We immediately referred the Intellectual Property Law Committee's submission to the Office of International Law for an opinion. In an advice dated 14 August, Mr Burmester, principal adviser in the Office of International Law, confirmed his earlier advice that the Bill was in conformity with Australia's Berne obligations. He has rejected both grounds on which the IPLC reached its conclusion, which were to do with national treatment and formality. It may be convenient for the chamber if I tabled that opinion.

The Opposition has also proposed a second reading amendment to the Bill: firstly, asking Australia to promote a uniform regime in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; and, secondly, asking Australia to seek clarification or amendment of the Berne Convention and the Universal Copyright Convention concerning trade and distribution in intellectual property rights. I inform the chamber that Australia has been and will continue to be substantially involved in both these international matters.

In respect of the Uruguay Round negotiations on trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights-TRAIPS-Australia has been strongly pushing for a uniform regime on both standards and enforcement of intellectual property rights. However, Australia, along with many other countries, has not been advocating the inclusion of importation rights as part of the agreement.

In respect of the international copyright conventions, Australia has traditionally been a very active participant in international meetings and will be attending a meeting on a possible protocol to the Berne Convention later this year. It is likely that the possible inclusion of importation rights in the convention will be raised and discussed as an issue at the meeting. As Australia has already taken a strong stance on these two matters, there is no need or reason for the proposed second reading amendment and the Government will not be supporting its passage. However, the Government does seek the early passage of the second reading of this Bill, which I commend to the chamber.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of this Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY BILL 1991UNIVERSITY OF CANBERRA AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian National University Bill 1991 and the University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991 are likely to have only a brief debate in the Senate. However, this is in huge contrast with their consideration in the House of Representatives where the legislation was guillotined through without one word being spoken and without the amendment that the Government moved even being understood by that chamber because it was not referred to. On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate that we will be supporting the two Bills before us, especially as they contain the late amendment that the Opposition had urged and which the Government has itself now moved. We will not be moving any additional amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not outline all the purposes of the two Bills as these were addressed in part by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) in the second reading speeches. However, I will refer to some purposes of the legislation which, remarkably, have not been addressed by the Minister. I will also make a few observations about the Government's attitude to these two important higher education institutions-the Australian National University and the University of Canberra.

The ANU Bill has the particular purpose of providing for the amalgamation of the ANU with the Canberra Institute of the Arts from 1 January 1992. Amalgamations have been a big part of the disruptive and centralist Dawkins agenda for higher education and the Opposition has opposed the idea of amalgamations being forced by the Government rather than being by independent decision of the institutions concerned. However, in this case-and it is one of the rare cases-the Opposition raises no objection to the amalgamation. It is a sensible amalgamation-it is not a shotgun marriage-which was requested and supported by both the ANU and the institute.

Many months ago when discussion about the amalgamation first began, I was able to visit both the ANU and the fine arts and the music part of the Canberra Institute of the Arts. In every conversation I found real support for the principle of this amalgamation. All the Government needed to do was to ensure that some of the existing broad purposes of the Institute, particularly extending tuition beyond matriculated students or enrolled undergraduates, continued. These quite practical concerns have been sensibly considered and are taken into account in the terms of the amalgamation which we now support.

It goes without saying that both the ANU, a very important national university, and the institute, one of the finest arts institutions in Australia, are highly commendable higher education institutions in this country. We wish them well in this new amalgamation as the enhanced Australian National University. Mr Deputy President, I am very aware that you are a member of the Council of the ANU and that the purposes of that university are close to your heart and mind. I will talk about this Parliament's representatives a little later in my speech.

It is interesting that much of the Minister's second reading speech was not about the Bill at all; it was a rather defensive statement about the Government's approach to funding for the Institute of Advanced Studies at the ANU. This was an enormous distraction because it is not the Institute of the Arts but the already long-existing research institution within the ANU-the Institute of Advanced Studies. I do not need to repeat my criticism of the way the evaluation of this research institute was handled and the way in which this Government responded in trying to subvert the proper responsibilities of the university in its own conduct of the research work of the Institute. Honourable senators will recall that the Government wanted to force the ANU and the University of Canberra-two large universities-to merge. It was only after there was massive resistance to this by the ANU, by the community and by the Opposition in this Parliament that the Government dropped that idea.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was referring to the ANU Bill and the University of Canberra Amendment Bill. I indicated that the Opposition will support both Bills and, indeed, the Government amendment for which we called. I was speaking of the attempts by the Government to amalgamate various universities. Many of these amalgamations have been unwise and forced and ought to have been resisted by the university communities, by the public at large and in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Notoriously, the Government of the day, especially Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin, have had several attempts to try to amalgamate the ANU with the University of Canberra. Personally, I have resisted those amalgamations because, unlike the one involved in the Bill amending the Australian National University Act, the earlier attempts were not sensible.

As a second-best attempt at interference in the ANU, the Government has been considering proposals for changing the funding for the Institute of Advanced Studies at the ANU, with the Australian Research Council being given the task by Ministers Dawkins and Baldwin of advising on the Institute of Advanced Studies. This would be a unique mechanism. No other institution is subject to this. The Opposition again deplores and rejects the Government's persistent heavy-handed intervention in the internal decision making of the university.

With the need for a Bill to merge the ANU and the Canberra Institute of the Arts on the other hand, the opportunity has been taken by this amending Bill to completely rewrite the ANU Act, to bring it up to date and to systematically make it more readable and understandable. This is the first complete revision of the Act since it was passed in 1946. I do not criticise this; in fact, I support it. It is a useful exercise.

But I criticise the fact that the Minister's speech and the explanatory memorandum make no mention of this revision. The Minister has not referred to this major rewriting and updating, however admirable its purpose. It is disgraceful that such a significant purpose of the Bill is not disclosed to the Parliament by the Government. Indeed, there was no mention of it in the House of Representatives' consideration of the Bill because there was not one word of debate as a result of the Bill being guillotined.

I do not know why the Government is so coy about omitting to describe this, since this revision is satisfactory and quite defensible. The rewording of clauses, the reordering of clauses into a more logical order and the general overhaul of the Act has been done well, and we welcome it. All I am saying is that the Government should have drawn attention to it in putting this Bill before us.

There is one aspect that particularly affects the Parliament and which the Government did not mention. Again, it is a surprising omission that the Minister, in introducing a Bill, did not even mention that the Bill will halve the Council of the ANU. The Council will be reduced to its smallest number in the entire history of the Australian National University.

I think it is actually a practical and sensible reform. The Opposition supports this change in the composition of the Council of the ANU. But I cannot understand why the Minister failed to mention this. Most of the categories of persons on the Council as currently constituted will have reduced numbers. Not only is the Opposition supporting this but also it is conscious of the support given by the ANU itself to this reform of its Council.

We have not received any direct representations from any interested party to oppose this change. My own inclination is to support the change, which will make the Council smaller, more manageable, practical and less verbose. The Council will be all the stronger for that. I cannot see disadvantages arising from the reduced numbers.

Throughout the entire history of the ANU, the Parliament has been represented, as you know, Mr Deputy President, by two members of the House of Representatives and two members of the Senate. You, Mr Deputy President, are one of those parliamentary representatives. In the reform, this number will be halved. One of the two members will be the nominee of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the other will be the nominee of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), and those nominees may come from either House of the Parliament. This is a significant change.

The Government should have openly consulted with the Opposition about this change. I am not aware of any discussion at all, however sensible I think the outcome is. The two senators currently on the ANU Council are yourself, Mr Deputy President, and my colleague Senator Lewis. The two senators have been elected by the Senate for terms which run until 17 July 1992. Presumably, when this Bill comes into effect, the amended ANU Act will abruptly terminate the senators' terms.

I note that the House of Representatives recently reappointed its two members, Dr Catley and Mr Ruddock, whose terms had almost expired, but they were reappointed only until the commencement of this Bill as an Act. Whilst we have not had the chance of direct personal discussion about this Bill, I discussed the whole matter with my Opposition colleague Senator Lewis. He also strongly supports the reduction in the size of the Council.

The Government's handling of these Bills in the House of Representatives was deplorable. Under the ruthless guillotine applied by the Government, there was no debate on the ANU Bill and very little on the University of Canberra Amendment Bill. That is in itself disgraceful. But I observe that for some years now a number of us have been saying that there is only one legislative chamber left in this Parliament, and that is the Senate.

Because of the iron majority, almost by definition, of the Government of the day in the other place, there is a singular lack of any mature possibility of a Bill proposed by the Government of the day being amended. I get the impression that what passes for legislative debate has its effect perhaps six months, two or more years hence after that debate in a telling argument being put by the other side of the House.

It is the case in this chamber that we sit longer hours and we are not, as a norm, guillotined. It is possible for majorities against the Government to amend legislation and, indeed, to throw legislation out. I make the observation that here again is another example of the Senate as a legislative chamber that is substantial and, I think, mature in the way in which it actually examines legislation. The Government, having guillotined this Bill, in the confusion of the guillotine has proceeded to insert some amendments while offering no explanation for them. I think that is treating that part of the Parliament with contempt.

The University of Canberra Amendment Bill is mainly the product of a long-running dispute between the Federal Government, in particular Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin, and the former ACT Government about the ACT Government's representatives on the Council of the University of Canberra. The ACT Government wished to nominate two members of the ACT legislature-one from the Australian Labor Party and one from the Residents Rally. This seems to me and to the Opposition to have been a reasonable step to take if the ACT Government regarded these people as the most appropriate persons to nominate to the University of Canberra Council.

It is frequently the case around Australia that State legislatures have representatives on the councils of universities within their borders. Given the particular local role of the University of Canberra it makes sense for the Territory's legislature to be represented on the Council, in just the same way as in every other capital city in Australia. Yet, with extraordinary arrogance, the Federal Ministers, Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin, rejected those nominees and insisted that members of the ACT Parliament were not acceptable. There was a stand-off for many months, making in part the University of Canberra Council not fully operational.

I was particularly concerned that for some of the meetings of the Council there was in fact a majority of in-house university members on the Council. These highly responsible people were rightly on the council but were representing, as the Vice Chancellor did, the whole university, or representing the staff or other internal interests of the university. In my view, no university council should have a majority of persons who have a direct financial and other interest in the actual decisions of that council. There ought to be a majority of external representatives on any such council.

It is no secret that some months ago the then Vice-Chancellor of the University of Canberra came to see me, amongst many in this Parliament, to say that the Council was not fully workable and to ask whether there was any way of getting through the impasse that existed between the Federal Labor Ministers and the coalition and Liberal Ministers of the ACT Legislative Assembly. I put my mind to the matter. Mr Baldwin will recall my putting a proposal to him which happened to be personally well received at the time. Now, at the end of all these many months, far too many months for this Federal Government to have not been properly responsible to the University of Canberra, there is now this quite happy outcome.

In my view, the great delay reflects no credit on the Minister's judgment. The stalemate dragged on and this Bill as originally drafted would actually have put into law the attitude of the Federal Government Ministers, which I have described. As I say, without any explanation and at the last minute, the proposition that we had been putting forward was put in as a Government amendment. I welcome the amendment nevertheless. It does meet the proposition that I and others in the Opposition had advocated. We are glad to see the Government's stalemate, as it were, collapse.

I can only suppose that Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin adopted their partisan view up until the time it looked as though the Liberal Government in the ACT would be defeated. We now have a Labor Government in the ACT. I can say only that that is the appearance; that the Ministers' stand-off evaporated as soon as their mates were in control of the ACT Government. That is no way to run a country. It is no way to make proper arrangements to stand for years for the good government of a university.

I will be the first to apologise if I can be convinced by the Ministers that there was any other reason, any reason of other substance, that led to this happy outcome whereby a proposal that many of us had supported is now being incorporated in this Bill. The reason that I do know is that no explanation was given for the Government's amendment when it was introduced into the House of Representatives. We deplore the process but we welcome the eventual outcome. It does not reflect well on the Federal Labor Government. Had the amendment, as now moved by the Government, been adopted right from the beginning there would have been none of the fuss and none of the concerns about the good government of the University of Canberra Council. I repeat that the Opposition supports both Bills and supports the amendment moved by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be opposing either the Australian National University Bill 1991 or the University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991. The amendments moved by the Government in the lower House satisfy our concerns in that they are rather innocuous in their effect as far as the organisations are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National University Bill provides for the amalgamation of the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts. There has been no objection to us regarding this merger so we see every reason to endorse the amalgamation. However, it is the case that the Government originally intended to effect a three-way merger including the Canberra College of Advanced Education, now the University of Canberra. This would have raised some considerable objection from us. In fact, any mention of such a merger will continue to raise our objections.

Three years ago the Australian Democrats opposed the merger on the ground that it was patently absurd. We opposed the merger for many reasons, including the fact that these institutions served different and distinct purposes. Our bottom line was that there was no educational benefit which we could perceive as being achieved by such a merger. It has been most disappointing that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) in his statement of 27 March this year on higher education in the ACT refused to rule out and, in fact, contemplated, a possible merger of the ANU and the University of Canberra at some future date. I share Senator Teague's concerns about the Government's attitude towards these institutions. I endorse his description of that attitude and his concern that it is a disruptive and centralist policy.

However, the other function of the ANU Bill that we are considering tonight is to reduce the size of the ANU's Council from 44 to 22 members, with the Chair of the Institute finishing that appointment as a twenty-third member during 1992. The Council will include two members appointed by the Chief Minister of the ACT, although they cannot be members of the Legislative Assembly. However, the Council already does include two Commonwealth parliamentarians and the ANU's administration is satisfied with these new Council arrangements.

The Council will maintain a similar balance of university and non-university appointees and will go from 20 staff and student members and 24 external members to nine and 13 respectively. Its new size seems reasonable and more in keeping with other universities. I recall one letter addressed to me on this matter which supported this reduction because of the unwieldy nature of the larger Council. While we have that in mind, the Democrats wish to note that some academics fear that the smaller Council could well be more susceptible to any future government moves for an amalgamation with the University of Canberra-that size is strictly a front, and there is the possibility of using it to expand opposition.

There will now be only one representative of some major categories of the university population, with no provision for substitutes if the sole representative is unable to attend a Council meeting. Undergraduate students, postgraduate students, Institute academic staff, faculty academic staff and university general staff will each only have one representative of their particular points of view. Each of those groups would remain unrepresented at some meetings if the sole Council member for that category was away. It does reduce the impact of the population, but it is only a minor concern and it is only perhaps my suspicious nature that leads me to express that concern here.

The University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991 provides for the Chief Minister of the ACT Legislative Assembly to appoint two persons to that university Council. When this Bill was introduced, those nominees could not be members of the ACT Legislative Assembly. I believe that that proposal was extraordinary. It would have been opposed by the Democrats. As a matter of fact, we expressed our dissatisfaction when it was first mentioned. The appointment of local politicians is standard procedure at other Australian universities, and it is reasonable and valuable for elected members to be sitting on university boards. It not only benefits the institutions to have that link, but it also allows informed debate on higher education-as we have the opportunity to hear informed debate-in this place because of the links that we have with university institutions and their representatives.

Since this Bill's introduction, the Federal Government has amended that suggestion, and will remove the restriction on the appointment of the local politicians to the university Council and we endorse that move. The reporting of that has been slightly colourful. I would not endorse the colourful nature of it, but suffice it to say that we are pleased to see that it has occurred.

The Australian Democrats support the amended Bill which allows for those MLAs to be represented. We have also argued for some time-and now renew the call on the Federal Government-for the introduction of legislation to transfer control of the University of Canberra to the ACT Government. This view has been supported by the Stephen Committee for Higher Education in the ACT, the University of Canberra, the ANU and even the Federal Opposition, as I recall.

In his 27 March statement, Mr Baldwin backed away from the immediate threat to dismember the ANU and to merge its faculties within the University of Canberra. The threat then shifted to the research arm of the Australian National University, that being the Institute of Advanced Studies. In a letter to the Australian National University last week, Mr Baldwin confirmed these Government plans, despite strong protests from the ANU itself, and it is with great concern that we have learned of this.

The plans include considering the role of the Australian Research Council in reviewing and advising on funding for each of the Institute's research schools. The Government has also indicated that the John Curtin School of Medical Research will be funded through the National Health and Medical Research Council. The ANU and the University of Canberra are also expected to jointly negotiate their educational profiles with the Commonwealth as the basis for the allocation of funds. The emphasis is on the word `jointly'.

Mr Baldwin is overstepping the mark in ignoring all objections to these proposals. I would have thought that the message might have sunk through by now. His persistence in following this line is really stubborn beyond belief and ill-advised. At this stage I will mention that the ANU maintains that the different schools within the Institute of Advanced Studies-the research arm of the ANU-should not be reviewed for funding as separate entities. It is well known that the attacks against the John Curtin School represent a small and secretive source. In the words of the ANU Administrator, Ron Hohnen, in the Canberra Times dated 20 May 1991, the Stephen Committee's original recommendations to turn the funding of the John Curtin School over to the NHMRC were `quite incredible and unsubstantiated findings'.

In conclusion, I hope that the Minister will respond to the many valid concerns about the Government's proposals. At least there will be further consultations-and I stress the word `consultations'-with the ANU over these matters. I have taken this opportunity to endorse this legislation and also to express our concerns for the other plans that the Government has for the Australian National University because they are so immediate. However, in this case we see absolutely nothing to criticise in the plans embodied in these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two Bills relating to the Australian National University and the University of Canberra and I will speak about these separately. The University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991 provides for certain administrative changes. The Government finally caved in and allowed the Chief Minister of the ACT Legislative Assembly, rather than the Governor-General, to appoint ACT members directly to the Council. The Bill also provides for the membership of the University of Canberra Council to be increased from 17 to 22 members. In addition, the university is now able to appoint the Chancellor either from outside or inside the membership of its Council in line with other higher education institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will be supporting both of these Bills, but I wish to confine the remainder of my remarks to the second Bill. The Australian National University Bill 1991 provides for the amalgamation of the ANU and the Canberra Institute of Arts from 1 January 1992. The second reading speech refers to a statement made by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) earlier this year on arrangements for higher education in the Australian Capital Territory.

In that statement, he endorsed new administrative arrangements which will encourage the Australian National University and the University of Canberra to coordinate their efforts and to cooperate more closely in order to provide the best possible educational opportunities for the region. He also endorses new funding arrangements for the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University which, according to the Minister, enhance the Institute's role as a national resource and result in appropriate performance evaluation and peer review process to guarantee the best use of research funds.

The research schools of the Institute of Advanced Studies are to be funded in future by the Australian Research Council and, in the case of the John Curtin Medical School of Research, the National Health and Medical Research Council. This proposal was opposed by the Chancellor of the ANU, Sir Geoffrey Yeend, who was appalled by this entirely new funding proposal and the fact that it had been announced without any prior consultation. At the time, Sir Geoffrey said:

There was a time when governments were protective of academic independence. Now we have a quite open attempt to divide the university and bring it further under the control of a government department and government agencies . . . . As long as I am Chancellor I shall resist any such attempt.

The second reading speech states that Mr Baldwin met with the ANU Council in May and that this meeting provided the Minister with the opportunity to clarify a number of key points with the council. This meeting did little to allay the fears of the institute. There is still concern about the new funding and reporting arrangements which are deemed to threaten the autonomy of the university.

The most recent development in this saga is a letter from Mr Baldwin to the Vice-Chancellor of the ANU, in which he says that he is adamant that the decisions outlined in March about the future of higher education arrangements in the ACT will be implemented-that is, that the Australian Research Council will report to the Government on appropriate funding levels for the Institute of Advanced Studies, and that the Australian Research Council will review funding for the institute's seven research schools on a five-yearly basis.

In this letter to the Vice Chancellor the Minister indicates that he is not listening to further argument and that he has said his last words on this matter. He says that it is in `all our interests' to work cooperatively to implement these decisions. He says that he has noted the ANU concerns about the role of the Australian Research Council but believes it appropriate that the institute be assessed and that its funding be set against other potential users of research funds.

The Government might believe it is legitimate and appropriate to be able to receive expert advice from the Australian Research Council as the only body with a broad based knowledge of research activities throughout the higher education system as to the overall distribution of research funds between the Institute of Advanced Studies and the rest of the higher education system, but not so the scholars, the people who perform the valuable research at the Institute of Advanced Studies. The Baldwin pronouncements have created nothing but consternation. People at the institute are concerned that the proposal to place them under the financial control of the Australian Research Council could have very damaging consequences.

For example, the institute's industrial partners might wonder whether they should continue their collaborative research programs and maintain their financial commitments. In some cases, this amounts to millions of dollars in equipment and support. Multinational corporations have made investments in the ANU because they considered that this university was an Australian research flagship in higher education and would continue to hold a pre-eminent place. They are concerned that proposals that destroy or dilute the university's reputation in research, rearrange its funding or frighten away talented young graduates will do nothing to encourage interaction with foreign interests which is vital for the nation's good, especially in the high technology area.

But they are even more alarmed at the prospect of being at the mercy of the Australian Research Council. ANU academics believe that the ARC is heavily politicised. They have no faith in its judgment. The Research Council appears to have its own agenda with regard to the Institute of Advanced Studies. The Deputy Vice-Chancellor, Professor Max Neutze, is doubtful about the rationale of the Dawkins and Baldwin higher education proposals. He says:

. . . the whole rationale of the higher education reforms has been to harness research to national needs and to make government and its various councils the main arbiters of what national needs are and to use the ARC to achieve it.

On the other hand, Professor Neutze believes there is a great advantage in having a plurality of sources in decisions about research priorities. Other academics are concerned about the proposed loss of plurality in research funding. They argue that if the research agenda were determined by the same people then bio-medical research, for instance, might be subject to the same mistakes. Under the Baldwin proposals, the John Curtin School of Medical Research is threatened with subjection to the National Health and Medical Research Council funding authority. The school is justifiably perturbed by attacks on an institution which has an excellent international reputation; it has produced a Nobel prize winner and received many other prestigious international prizes and has numerous fellows of the Royal Society.

The head of the Division of Cell Biology, Professor Bob Blanden, says that party political motives and ideology are attempting to level research in the institute by taking away its budget and reducing the amount of research that is done in the institute without any consideration for quality. He believes that the ANU is in imminent danger of being led down the Eastern European path. He says:
You have a unified system and everyone has to conform. You don't have diversity any more and if someone gets out of line you kick the stuffing out of them.

Professor Blanden predicted centralised control and planning without plurality and without freedom. Yet the whole point of basic research is that when one gets on the track of something new and exciting one goes after it, whether or not it is in the strategic plan. The most damaging aspect of the Baldwin proposal is perceived to be the proposal that funding for the Institute of Advanced Studies be the sum of the funding for the different research schools. That is seen to be taking away from the university its own responsibility for strategic planning and priority setting, which goes across all of the research schools.

The Baldwin proposal makes each of the schools a strategic research centre, and each is to be funded as such. This is seen to be the death knell of the institute. The report of Sir Ninian Stephen's review team concerning the Institute of Advanced Studies states:

. . . in most respects the Institute has met outstandingly well its charter of engaging in research and providing advanced training to the highest international standard and in areas of national importance to Australia.

The coalition recognises that the Australian Research Council has a legitimate role to play in the overall evaluation of research in Australian universities, but it should not use grant allocation powers to run the Institute of Advanced Studies. One does not put Dracula in charge of the blood bank.

The Liberal policy is to ensure and enshrine the autonomy of the universities, and when we are in government we will be returning to them much greater freedom to chart their own futures without the heavy conformist constraints presently placed upon them by the Commonwealth. Above all, we will scrap the present Government's policy guidelines for the Australian Research Council and establish a system that will reduce bureaucratic interference and ensure that excellence in research is supported to the full extent of the community's ability to pay.

The Government's justification for this entirely iniquitous interference with the autonomy and funding arrangements of the Institute of Advanced Studies occupies two-thirds of the second reading speech on the Australian National University Bill which, in the words of the Minister, is `entirely separate from these new arrangements for higher education in the ACT'. All of this was included in the second reading speech as a political exercise and had nothing to do with the present Bill, which simply proposes to amalgamate the Canberra Institute of the Arts with the Australian National University.

The Australian National University Bill is an amalgamation Bill. It is part of the Government's new unified national system of higher education to replace the previous binary system, which differentiates between universities and colleges of advanced education. Under the unified national system there are to be fewer and larger institutions of higher education as a result of the amalgamations. The Australian National University was in the firing line to be amalgamated with the then Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Canberra Institute of the Arts. We opposed that amalgamation because there were no educational or financial benefits to be gained from a merger between the Australian National University and the Canberra College of Advanced Education. But, on the other hand, there were serious disadvantages associated with industrial relations and vocational specialisation. The coalition opposes the Government's unified national system because it threatens the independence of higher education facilities all around Australia.

Although the Government withdrew the Australian National University Bill in 1988 which, in effect, would have created a three-way merger, that does not appear to be the end of the story. Only last Friday Mr Baldwin was reported to have said that, while he acknowledges that the ANU and the University of Canberra are separate institutions at present with freedom to develop separate academic profiles, there will still be joint negotiation of those profiles and the two universities should consider a federated model of amalgamation and proceed towards that end in the future. What he was trying to achieve in 1988 seems to be coming about in another way in 1991.

However, the merger of the two under the current proposal between the ANU and the Canberra Institute of the Arts is a different matter. The two institutions that make up the institute-the Canberra School of Music and the Canberra School of Art-are already situated next to the ANU campus and there has been a very strong liaison between the three establishments for many years. As I indicated earlier, the coalition will be supporting this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering two Bills, the Australian National University Bill 1991 and the University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991. I intend to speak almost entirely on the first, the Australian National University Bill, principally because I am one of the Senate's representatives on the Council of the Australian National University. Before considering aspects of the Bills, I would like to outline something of the history of the Australian National University because it is interesting to see where the university has come from to where it is now and to outline some of the problems that now face the university as a result of the way it has developed and the way that tertiary institutions throughout Australia have developed at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National University, or the ANU as most people refer to it, was originally established as a research and postgraduate institution under the Australian National University Act 1946. At that time the ANU was Australia's only research-oriented university. It remained a research institution only until 1960. In that year undergraduate teaching facilities were acquired through amalgamation with the Canberra University College. That college had, until then, awarded its degrees through the University of Melbourne. The original Australian National University then became the Institute of Advanced Studies. The undergraduate schools formed the School of General Studies, which later became known, and are now known, as the faculties. This gave the Australian National University two distinct but related parts-the Institute of Advanced Studies, the institute as it is called, and the faculties. There are now several research schools which carry out research and graduate training in the biological, medical, physical, chemical, earth and social sciences as well as in the important area of Pacific studies.

The teaching departments or faculties are in the Faculties of Arts, Asian Studies, Economics and Commerce, Law and Science. There is considerable interaction between the two parts of the university and this is increasing. The statutory functions of the university, as specified in the Australian National University Act 1946, are:
(a) the encouragement and provision of facilities for graduate research and study, both generally and in relation to subjects of national importance to Australia; and
(b) the provision of facilities for university education for persons who elect to avail themselves of those facilities and who are eligible to do so.

The first of these two functions broadly describes what occurs in the Institute of Advanced Studies. The second describes one of the main functions of the faculties. The faculties, however, have a commitment to research and graduate training in a similar way to other Australian universities. The institute constitutes about two-thirds of the academic life of the university and the faculties the other third.

The four original schools of the Institute of Advanced Studies were the Research Schools of Pacific Studies, Physical Sciences and Social Sciences and the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It was not until 1967 that two more research schools were added. These were Biological Sciences and Chemistry. In 1973 the Research School of Earth Sciences was added to the institute. These particular fields of research were chosen because of their importance to Australia or because they could be studied to advantage in Australia.

Although it consists of two separate but interacting parts, the university operates under a single administration, headed by the Vice-Chancellor, and governed by a council composed of 44 members. Members of the council are elected representatives of academic and general staff, graduate and undergraduate bodies and the Convocation of the University. Four representatives are elected by the Federal Parliament, two from the Senate and two from the House of Representatives, and some are appointed by the Governor-General. The council meets about eight times a year under the chairmanship of the Chancellor.

The Australian National University Bill makes what I consider to be two major changes. The Bill provides for the amalgamation of the Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts as from 1 January next year. The Australian National University and the Canberra Institute of the Arts actually finalised an affiliation agreement to amalgamate by 1 January this year. Legislation to give effect to that amalgamation has therefore been long awaited both by the ANU and the Institute of the Arts.

The Bill abolishes the Institute of the Arts as a separate institution and adds to the functions of the university the requirement that it provide facilities for courses at higher education and other levels in the visual and performing arts. The Bill also provides for students and staff of the Institute of the Arts to be transferred to the university on terms and conditions no less favourable than they enjoy at present.

The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, has said that the amalgamation can be expected to enhance the national and international roles of the university through the addition of the visual and performing arts to its range of disciplines, while at the same time allowing the Institute of the Arts to become a member of the unified national system. It would not have been possible for the institute with its small student load to become a member of the unified national system of higher education in its own right. Mr Baldwin, in his second reading speech in relation to this amalgamation, said:

The amalgamation will permit students from both institutions to benefit from a wider range of course options. The development of higher degree courses at the Institute of the Arts will benefit from the university's greater experience in graduate education. In addition, the consolidation of adjacent campuses under one administration will lead to cost efficiencies and the rationalisation of shared services and amenities. The local community can expect to enjoy greater benefits from an expansion of university extension programs with the addition of more musical, art, and gallery activities.

The second major change is that the Bill also provides for changes to the composition of the council. This matter was mentioned earlier by previous speakers and Senator Teague went into it in a fair amount of detail. Most of those who have been members of the council would agree that a 44-member council is far too large. The new council will comprise about half that number and, because of that, the representation from the Federal Parliament will be reduced to two members from the current four members. As a long time representative of the Senate on the university council, I consider that having fewer members on the council will streamline the council's operations.

I mention some of those who will be members of the council. Honourable senators will be able to see that some of these members will be from within the university and some will be external. The internal members include the Chancellor, the Pro-Chancellor, the Vice-Chancellor, the chairperson of the board of the institute and the chairperson of the board of the faculties. People from outside the university include four persons appointed by the Governor-General-I imagine that the appointment of those four persons by the Governor-General will be on the advice of the Government of the day-one person being a senator or member of the House of Representatives, appointed by the Governor-General on the nomination of the Prime Minister; and one person being a senator or a member of the House of Representatives appointed by the Governor-General on the nomination of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives. It is likely, from those two positions, that we would have one person from the Government and one person from the Opposition-unless, of course, the Australian Democrats were interested in obtaining a place on the council and convinced the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition to nominate one of them.

Two persons are to be appointed by the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory. These positions are new. No persons were appointed to the former council at the recommendation of the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory. As Senator Teague outlined, these persons are not to be members of the Legislative Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. Other persons-some from within the university, including staff and student representatives, and also people from outside the university-will be appointed to the council.

Although it is not particularly pertinent to the Bill under discussion, I would like to make a brief comment about the future role of the university. When the Institute of Advanced Studies was established, there was little major research work being carried out in universities in Australia. The present situation, however, is far different. There are many major universities in the Commonwealth and some of these carry out excellent research work. Without denigrating other universities in Queensland, I consider research undertaken at the University of Queensland and at the Queensland University of Technology to be world-class.

Honourable senators would be able to give examples of similar research being carried out in the States they represent. This does not mean that the Institute of Advanced Studies is no longer relevant, but it does mean that the institute has to compete with other higher education institutions for the research money made available by the Federal Government. This has created some difficulties because, for a long time, any review of research activities in the institute has been by peer review. With other institutions vying for research funds, however, some form of external review of the institute's activities is essential. Neither the university as a whole nor the institute has fully come to grips with this new development.

The ANU was once the only university in Canberra. There are, however, university facilities at the University of Canberra and at the military establishments in the city. Canberra can probably accommodate two universities, but in some areas it would be best if significant cooperation could take place between the ANU and the University of Canberra. I cannot speak with authority about the University of Canberra in this regard, but the ANU has not yet come to terms with this particular development. For the benefit of students in the Canberra region, as well as those who come from more far-flung areas, and for the benefit of academic excellence, this factor will have to be addressed in the near future.

Before concluding, I would like to comment on a matter that Senator Teague mentioned. He implied-a little tongue-in-cheek, I think-that perhaps the amendment in relation to the Bill for the University of Canberra came about because the Federal Government saw that there was about to be a change of government in the ACT and decided to acquiesce and introduce the Bill in its current form. I think that that is probably incorrect. I have not checked with Mr Baldwin, and I am not quite sure that I will either. However, I do not think it is correct. I saw the Bill very early in the year when it was ready to go and, if my recollection is correct, it was in its current form. I note that the Bill to amend the University of Canberra Act was sent from the House of Representatives to the Senate on 30 May 1991. About seven days after that there was a change of government in the ACT.

The Bill had been in the House of Representatives for some time. I would agree with Senator Teague that it was not debated very well in the House of Representatives, but it had been there for some time. When the Bill came to us there had not been a change of government in the ACT. I think it is probably coincidental that the two events occurred fairly close together, rather than there being any specific plan to put the Bill forward because there was a change of government in the ACT, or one was impending. Like the Minister, I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was quoted in the Australian newspaper of 13 March 1991 as observing that securing the future of Australia involves being, like Japan and Germany, `a clever country' and that `the foundation of a clever country is its education system'. I do not think there would be any Australians who would argue with those sentiments, but the reality is a long way from it. Any hope of Australia's becoming a clever country has, I believe, been shattered by the insensitivity and destructive power of the Dawkins approach to education and, ultimately, the irresponsibility of the Government's handling of higher education in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening we are debating the University of Canberra Amendment Bill 1991 and the Australian National University Bill 1991. The University of Canberra Amendment Bill provides for a variation in the audit requirements of the University of Canberra and a change in the qualifications and method of appointment of members of the council from the ACT, including an amendment to permit the Chief Minister of the ACT to appoint members of the Legislative Assembly to the council of the University of Canberra.

This aspect of the legislation has been touched upon by others in this debate, and I see little purpose in going over it again, except to marvel at the way the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) seeks to say that the ACT Government should be able to appoint someone to the council but that it should not be one of its own number. The Minister knows full well that this chamber and the House of Representatives appoint people to the council of the Australian National University and appoint from their own number. The Minister sought to take it upon himself to decide that those elected by the people of the ACT were not sufficiently worthy to be appointed to the council of the University of Canberra. He held out for a very long time against permitting the ACT Government to be able to appoint one of its own number to the council of the University of Canberra.

The ANU Bill effects the amalgamation of the Canberra Institute of the Arts and the Australian National University. Unlike many other amalgamations, and proposed amalgamations, this one has been an amiable resolution between the two institutions. In fact, the Bill has been long awaited by both parties. The Bill was introduced before Christmas last year and people were hoping that it would be passed then; they were certainly hoping that it would be passed in the autumn session this year. However, over the months the Bill has been caught up with the Government's other agenda for universities and amalgamations.

The two Bills before us tonight are not opposed by the Opposition, but there are things that need to be said about tertiary education, lest allowing them to pass without comment were to be taken as our generally agreeing to the line that the Australian Labor Party has pursued with respect to tertiary education.

I have spoken on this matter previously. The list of failures of the Government is still the same: the increasing interference and interventionist policies which are being pursued; the policy of forced amalgamations; the failure to make inroads into the level of unmet demand; the reduced funding per tertiary student; and the question of staff salaries. Of course, there has been a new salary package for academics but, when we think of how far they have been behind, I suspect that the academics are still out of pocket. In many institutions where there are significant over-enrolments, it can only be the staff who are carrying the burden of over-enrolments. If the Government is not paying and the students are not paying, it can only be a burden that is being borne by the staff of those institutions. The list of failures continues: the failure to provide tertiary institutions with the freedom and flexibility needed to address the impending shortage of academic staff; the neglect of the fundamental issue of quality in education; and the disruption and continuing insecurity as a result of the Government's policy over these recent years.

Turning to the matter of the increasing interference and interventionist policies of this Government, the whole higher education system is being brought under increasing and direct political control from Canberra. This has inevitably led to an undermining of institutional autonomy. The whole concept of a unified system and the intrusive educational profiles process continues to be an administrative nightmare and smacks of undue central control. I should like to quote from somebody whose credentials in tertiary education would not be denied. I refer to Mr Frank Hambly, the Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee. On 28 September 1990 he said:

There is little doubt that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is attempting to achieve a uniform system of tertiary education and not just a unified system. This whole policy is more about central control than national standards.
I would suggest that everybody ought to listen to the words and comments of Mr Hambly.

We have, too, the argument of Professor Peter Karmel in August 1989 that the Dawkins reforms meant that the Federal Government was intervening more in tertiary institutions and he warned that the bureaucratic tendency to coordinate-which really means control-must be watched closely. Then on 28 May this year, when introducing a statement in the other place, Mr Baldwin indicated that the Government would transfer funding from the John Curtin School of Medical Research to the National Health and Medical Research Council, and that separate reviews would be conducted of each of the research schools and centres of the Institute of Advanced Studies on a five-yearly basis. These reviews were to recommend directly to the Minister the levels of funding for each school and centre. In other words, the John Curtin School of Medical Research would no longer be the institution that it had been, that is, it would not be able to obtain its funding and to decide on the research which should be undertaken. It would virtually be under the direct control of the Minister following the changes.

The implication of these decisions is unmistakable. They are aimed at breaking up the Institute of Advanced Studies and removing effective control of the institute from the university. I do not doubt that anybody who has followed this debate has any doubt at all that that is the aim of the Minister as far as the Institute of Advanced Studies is concerned.

In addition, the decision to place the institute under the control of the Australian Research Council is directly contrary to the recommendations of the Stephen Committee which reviewed the institute and made a specific and clear recommendation that this should not happen. The Stephen Review for higher education in the ACT emphasised and endorsed the most important principle that research funding in this country should not be under monopolistic control but should come from a variety of sources so that a different perspective could be brought to bear on the merits of different areas of inquiry.

Understandably, the Australian National University Council has objected most strongly to this review process because of the threat it poses to the university's autonomy and to freedom of inquiry. The ANU, I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, faces a far greater level of control than that of any other university in Australia and it is, therefore, easier for the Minister to attempt to do this at this university. These quite legitimate concerns about unnecessarily intrusive controls are reflected nationally and internationally.

The review arrangements will mean, in effect, that the Institute of Advanced Studies will be managed not by the ANU Council but by government research councils. The ANU will become a university that no longer sets its own research agenda or allocates its own resources. Support for the ANU Council's efforts to preserve the university's integrity and autonomy is widespread. I quote from Professor Peter Karmel who said in the ANU Reporter:
The ANU is an outstanding institution and is recognised as such internationally . . .

It contains a great concentration of distinguished scholars and scientists, as can be testified objectively by an examination of the membership of the learned academies of Australia, the United Kingdom and elsewhere, and by its output of research and publications.
I do not think there is any doubt that the Government is attempting to destroy the Australian National University.

The interesting thing in the debate over the months and years that it has now gone on, apart from its very disruptive nature, has been that never once have I heard the Minister talking about benefits to students. It has always been something else. It would be my view that the universities are there to benefit the students of this country, to see that they get the sort of education needed, and that there be some hope of fulfilling the idea that we should become a clever country. But never once has the Minister talked about a benefit to students.

The Government has failed to make any inroads into a level of unmet demand in tertiary institutions. They are being squeezed with declining funding and a sharp rise in the number of students at universities, and this is causing a deepening crisis. The Government is very keen to boast about retention rates of students continuing to year 12 in secondary schools. The inevitable consequence of this, if there is any success at all in the education systems of this country, is that students will then wish to proceed to tertiary education. Yet the opportunity for them to do so is limited.

It may well be that some of those students proceeding to year 12 would have been better, at perhaps year 10, to have gone into other courses whereby they may have been able to obtain employment rather than to have been misled into thinking that there was something magical about year 12 following which they could not proceed with their education. It is time that somebody had a think about that if there is to be no effort to make the places available.

The Government has failed to recognise that increased participation rates raise the expectation of children leaving school. I understand that at the University of Canberra at present there are about 23 per cent more students than the funding provided for. Some measures will need to be taken by the university to introduce controlled admissions for 1992 so that this does not happen again. I have heard a number of explanations as to why there have been such massive over-enrolments. I find none of them terribly convincing, and I do not understand how it could reach massive proportions. Some over-enrolments I can understand but, as I said earlier, if the Government is not paying by giving funds to the universities and if the students are not paying, it is definitely members of the staff who are bearing the unfair burden of these additional student numbers.

There is also the question of the failure to provide institutions with the freedom and flexibility needed to address the impending shortage of academic staff. It has been suggested that there will be a shortage of up to 25,000 staff by the year 2000. What is going to be done to correct that imbalance? Again, it is all very well to be encouraging students to complete year 12 and have the expectation that they can proceed to a tertiary course. If there are no staff to teach them, we are not doing them much of a favour at all.

There has been a neglect of the fundamental issue of quality in education. I turn to the remarks of Senator Aulich, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, who acknowledged that the Minister is so absorbed in financial and structural change that he has neglected the fundamental issue of quality in tertiary education. Uniformity does not automatically produce quality in tertiary education, and I think it is time that the Minister thought about that. The Government may well boast a 50 per cent increase in tertiary enrolments since Labor came into Government, but funding has declined by 11 per cent. As a proportion of our gross domestic product, Commonwealth expenditure on higher education was 1.05 per cent in 1980-81. In 1989-90 it was 0.85 per cent. There is, as a consequence, continuing disruption and insecurity in higher education.

In July 1988 the proposal to amalgamate the ANU with the then Canberra College of Advanced Education was first put forward as part of the Dawkins plan for higher education. It was evident that the Minister was more concerned with administrative neatness and control than with increasing educational standards. He was more concerned about administration than he was about the benefit to students.

At the relatively early stage of August 1989 in this ongoing and disruptive saga, the Minister was quoted in a press article as being sympathetic to the concerns raised by the university and the CCAE about the damage that would be done to their academic programs if there were to be continuing, drawn-out uncertainty about their future status and mission, yet from August 1989 he has not worried in the slightest about the impact of the disruptive path which he has been determined to follow. In September 1989 the proposed amalgamation of the ANU, the CCAE and the Canberra Institute of the Arts was called off after the ANU Council voted against the merger. The Canberra Times reported the following on 13 September 1989:
There will definitely be no amalgamation between the ANU and the CCAE, according to the Minister for Education, John Dawkins.

What are we to think about that statement and the Minister's motives when he said it? I really cannot comment on that, but it certainly was not the end of the matter. In January 1990 he was back at it again. The report of the Stephen committee was presented in November 1990. He obviously did not like what he found in that report, so what did he do? He employed Professor Ian Chubb to review the Stephen report and, purportedly, to tell him how the Stephen report should be implemented. Anybody who has read both reports would know that there is very little in common between the two and, I would say, absolutely no relation between them. I am not quite sure how that came about, but it was very clear to me from reading those reports that the implementation of the Stephen report was not in any way associated with the recommendations of the Chubb report. The Chubb report has been opposed very strongly within the ANU. Many would be aware of the number of petitions that have been presented in this place, urging the Government not to proceed with the merger, not to proceed to destroy the institutions that have served this community and Australia so well.

I come back to the point that I have already made about the Government having a go again at the Institute of Advanced Studies by interfering with the funding of the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It is interesting to reflect on what Minister Dawkins said on 15 June 1989:
. . . this Government has explicitly stated that it will support only mergers which have the support of the institutions concerned.

He seems to say one thing but do another. We can only laugh at that comment when we review what in fact has happened with the institutions in the Australian Capital Territory. But the Government's plan to amalgamate the ANU and the University of Canberra is not dead even now. When we look at the statements of Mr Baldwin in the other place on 28 May 1991, we see that he invited the councils of the ANU and the University of Canberra to consider a federated model of amalgamation of the two institutions `with progress to full integration'. It is quite clear that the Government is absolutely determined to have its way in this matter, no matter the evidence before it, no matter the disruption to the institutions and the students and staff of those institutions. The continuing uncertainty about the future of the ANU has caused enormous morale problems within the ANU and has significantly damaged the university's ability to attract and keep top quality staff and students. I refer to a Canberra Times article of 23 May 1991:

Professor Osmond warned that though the world-wide chorus of derision would soon abate, the humiliation of Australian academe, and denial of its autonomy, would drive the ``highest fliers away in droves''.

What a fine outcome for the policies of this Minister. I hope that he is not proud of what he has achieved. There is evidence now that there is to be a national campaign against the Government over its handling of higher education. A recent article in the ANU Reporter talks of the steps some academics are planning to take to let people know what is happening. I believe that it is important that Australians understand and fully appreciate the attack on tertiary education by looking at the microcosm of the ACT and what in fact has happened with the Australian National University and the University of Canberra.

It will be a tragedy if these two institutions are destroyed by whatever it is that drives this Minister towards his particular brand of socialism in the area of tertiary education. I support the two Bills that we are discussing this evening, but I think it is important that we keep in mind exactly what we are facing in this very important area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
