DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 August, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991 as far as it provides wildlife protection. This Bill amends the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 which regulates the export and import of flora and fauna. Australia is a party to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna and cooperates with the Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce, known as TRAFFIC. As well as increasing penalties for illegal actions, the Bill contains changes aimed at increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of legitimate trade in wildlife and wildlife products.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with the main elements of the Bill, I point out that this Bill and its method of presentation is an example of the sort of messy management we tend to get from the Government. It rushes legislation into the other place and then finds that it has made a mess of it and has to go back and correct it. Honourable senators will no doubt be intrigued to note that in the House of Representatives Hansard of 21 June 1991 on pages 5298 and 5299 a whole host of amendments had to be made to the Bill before it even got out of that chamber.

By way of protest from the Opposition I might say that we are getting pretty sick and tired of slapdash, half-baked legislation, no matter how well intentioned, coming into the House of Representatives and being rushed through without proper debate and proper preparation, and then being subject to substantial amendment. That does not detract from the fact that we support the thrust of this legislation. We just wish that this process could be done more efficiently.

The main provisions of the Bill increase custodial penalties from five to 10 years for wildlife smuggling; tighten a definition in the Act to prevent importers using Australia as a holding area while they arrange markets in other countries; restrict to six the maximum number of household pets people may take with them when leaving Australia; and give the Minister greater flexibility in determining whether to allow trade in certain common species without the need for a management plan.

We support this Bill because the coalition's environment policy which substantially predates this Bill-it was released in February 1990-strongly supports all the things that the Bill is setting out to do. In particular, the coalition's environment policy at that time specifically called for stronger penalties. It said:

The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 will be kept up to date, the penalties under it increased and more resources devoted to its enforcement. The States will be encouraged to introduce complementary legislation to support this regime.
The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna (CITES) will be supported fully and Australia will play a more active role in its further development.
We will continue to co-operate with the excellent work done by TRAFFIC (Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce).

We are very glad to see that the Government has followed the policy statement that was put out by the Opposition before the 1990 election. It is in fact following the Opposition's lead. I commend the Government for having the humility and the good sense to do what the Opposition has recommended.

I also mention that in New South Wales, the Minister for Environment, Mr Tim Moore, announced three years ago that the Greiner Government would double penalties for smuggling to 10 years gaol. That has since been done. Mr Moore also called on the Commonwealth to step up its enforcement efforts. So I stress that basically what the Government is doing with this legislation is what the coalition Opposition in the Federal arena has been pressing for and what the Liberal-National State Government in New South Wales had been urging it to do.

In the second reading speech in the other place, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) referred to a recent court action in which the judge specifically remarked on the desirability of a heavier penalty. Discussions that the shadow Minister for environment, Mr Chaney, has had with one prominent private operator in the nature conservation field and with the head of a State government authority have confirmed his view about growing interest in alternative means of protecting native Australian wildlife. For example, the development of commercial breeding and controlled trade has benefited wildlife populations in parts of Africa and elsewhere and merits further investigation, given that blanket prohibition guarantees very high prices on the illegal market. In other words, a little bit of lateral thinking in this area could well be fairly useful in resolving what is becoming a problem of some magnitude.

The Opposition is not yet in a position to pursue this matter by making any formal recommendations or proposed amendments to this legislation, but I do think that it is a matter that the Government could look at. After all, it has taken advice from the Opposition in all the other elements of this Bill. Perhaps it could start taking some advice from us on adopting a more rational approach to this problem, as we recommend.

In any event, the coalition will not delay the House on this matter, apart from asking the Government to look at the general proposition that I have raised about alternative methods of dealing with the problem. I commend the Bill-heavily amended and heavily corrected-to the chamber. I thank the Government for having taken our very good advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991. I support my colleague Senator Michael Baume who has spoken today to this Bill. The purpose of this Bill, as has already been pointed out, is to allow the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to exempt the export and import of certain plant and animal specimens and to allow for an increase in the maximum term of imprisonment for offences against this Act from five years to 10 years, with or without a fine. It also allows the Minister to make certain declarations concerning management programs, including transport of such animals that are legalised for transport.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a vast number of successful prosecutions for offences against this Act. During 1988-89 there were at least 10 successful prosecutions by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and I understand that another 12 prosecutions are outstanding. This Bill seeks to apply a 10-year gaol sentence to this type of offence. Ten years in gaol is the sentence for serious offences and I think this will deter would-be illegal traffickers in native wildlife.

In this Bill there is no provision for legalising any export trade in live birds or animals. After giving the reasons for increasing penalties, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) in his second reading speech said:

Nor will these changes alter the current ban on private and commercial export of live native fauna. The arguments of those in favour of allowing commercial export of live native birds have been well documented in the media.

As Senator Michael Baume alluded to a moment ago, there could be an untapped trade out there, especially when a lot of this wildlife is in plague proportions and is also not protected from extermination by farmers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly when decimating wheat crops.

—Yes, that is right. These birds do not have the legal protection which endangered species have. The Government could look at the idea of exporting these birds under certain regulations, although the regulations would have to be very tight. Most of the native birds which are abundant and cause damage to crops are parrots or cockatoos. These birds are collectively referred to as psitticines. I am going to discuss this group of birds and suggest that the Government look at another export industry.
—That includes galahs, doesn't it?

—Yes, it does. The removal of the bans on the export of native birds has been suggested for a number of reasons: establishing an export industry; funding control of pest bird species; and making bird smuggling less economic. Of course, while birds are going out illegally, there is a black market with higher prices. Between $2,000 and $3,000 is available for a single bird so I suppose it is quite tempting to try to get some of that money.

SPEECH.PARA: Other reasons for removing the bans on export are: animal welfare improvements vis-a-vis smuggling; increased funding for policing of smuggling from revenue earned from exports; and, of course, reducing crop damage. I believe that most honourable senators have no idea about the amount of damage that parrots, wild ducks, et cetera, can do to a crop. Crops and dams near the crops provide both the water supply and the feed for the birds and they are naturally attracted to the area.

Who wants to slaughter the birds? I do not believe in slaughtering them but I have not found any other way of exterminating them- `exterminating' is not the right word; I mean keeping them away. I believe that a reasonable solution would be to trap some of these birds, breed from them in the environment and export the natural offspring, or export a certain number that have been captured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Help our balance of payments, too.

—Yes, of course. Establishing an export industry based on the sale of live native birds would undoubtedly assist Australia by earning export dollars. The question is what sort of industry should be established. The industry could be based on trapping native birds in the wild, raising hatchlings from eggs taken in the wild, breeding captive birds or a combination of all those things.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give the Senate a few figures to illustrate my point. In 1987, 700,000 birds were imported into the United States, with 580,000 being released onto the market. An estimated 40 per cent of these birds would have been the parrot species. The parrots are the birds in demand. At present, the United States is not getting parrots from Australia, so it is obviously getting them from somewhere else. I believe that the prime quota comes from Indonesia.

Another example is that, in 1981, 110,000 parrots were imported into Japan, although the importing of birds appears to have dropped since then. The EEC is the other principal market for birds. Some of the recent bird prices in the United States and United Kingdom are: a little corella costs $900 to $1,250; a galah costs $2,500 to $3,000 so we might find some use for some galahs here, because they are worth a bit of money; a sulphur crested cockatoo costs $2,250 to $3,500; and a Major Mitchell costs $6,000 to $12,500. So there is a market out there willing to pay for these birds.

Of course, birds bred in captivity as pets right from the beginning would attract double those prices as the mortality rate would be far less because they have been domesticated right from the beginning. A United States magazine recently advertised a hand reared Moluccan cockatoo for $2,400 while a wild one could be bought for only $500. I have quoted enough figures to show that an export industry could be set up. We have these native birds which are not protected because they are in plague proportions and the export of them would lessen the problems around the crops, virtually cut out illegal smuggling and could earn up to $4m a year for Australia. It would not be a big industry right from the word go but it could grow. The Minister at the table, Senator Collins, is looking rather doubtful about this but the figures I have quoted are correct. I would like to argue this matter in some other forum at another time.

The coalition supports this Bill. Animal welfare is a significant aspect in this Bill because, if the illegal trade is cut out, the mortality rate of exported birds goes down. From the figures quoted and the prosecutions, 90 per cent of illegally smuggled birds die in transit whereas, with controlled exports into the United States from other countries, the death rate in transport is 3 to 4 per cent, which is quite minimal. That is certainly lower than the mortality rate in the live sheep trade and I suppose it could even be lower than the mortality rate in human transport, depending on which airline one uses. Also, a certain number of deaths occur in quarantine in the importing country but pets or other animals can die even if they are transported from one end of the country to the other.

I went through these figures to give the Senate an idea about what we could be doing with the birds that are in plague proportions and do nothing but damage Australian agriculture. It may seem to the Senate, and especially to the Minister sitting over there, that this idea is a few years ahead of its time. However, with careful research, study into the trade, and securing the right outlets, I believe that such an industry could be set up for the benefit of whoever takes on the project, for the benefit of Australia and, of course, for the benefit of the farmers whose crops are damaged.

I will not delay the Senate any longer. The Opposition supports the Bill as it stands. I, too, must comment on the number of amendments made to the Bill even before it left the other House. The Opposition looks forward to the day when legislation of this sort is properly drafted and thought out before it arrives here, let alone in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleagues in the debate on the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, more than anybody, as Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, would be aware of the effect that imported feral animals have had on this country, but I will refer to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: Since Australia was first settled by Europeans a little over 200 years ago, 27 species of mammals and birds, along with around 100 species of plants, have become extinct. In addition, 59 species of mammals, birds, reptiles, frogs and fish, along with many hundreds of species of invertebrates, are considered endangered and will most likely become extinct within 10 or 20 years unless action is taken. It is in these circumstances that the coalition welcomes the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991, although we have a number of reservations about some failings of the Bill, which I shall detail later.

In essence, the Bill increases the penalty from five to 10 years for wildlife smuggling. It also attempts to prevent importers using Australia as a holding area whilst they arrange for markets to be found overseas. Under the Bill's provisions, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) will be allowed greater flexibility in determining whether to allow the trade of certain common species without a management plan.

It is worth mentioning that this Bill has been inexplicably delayed since it was first introduced into the other place on 22 August 1990. This means that it has now taken a year for the Bill to move from the other place to the Senate. Quite frankly, given that the loss of a species cannot be replaced, I consider this to be most unsatisfactory.

In bringing forward this Bill, the Government has essentially followed the Opposition's lead. In our environment policy, which was released in February 1990, we called for a beefing up of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act. We believed that the Act required tougher penalties. I quote from a certain section of our policy, which reads:
The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act of 1982 will be kept up-to-date and penalties under it increased and more resources devoted to its enforcement.

The coalition has always believed that endangered species should be protected. We support fully the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, which is called CITES. We also support the excellent work which has been done by the Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce, commonly known as TRAFFIC.

Illegal trade in native flora and fauna has existed for many years. In some sections of the community this trade is referred to as the fauna mafia-I have no questions about why Senator Panizza spoke on this tonight! There have been highly publicised cases of individuals who have been apprehended in the process of smuggling out of this country some of our endangered species. I remember when, not that long ago-others may have seen this-I saw an article in one of the newspapers about a number of drugged parrots stuffed down a tube, which first brought to my attention what has been going on around the place.

There have been many other publicised cases and they are referred to in the annual report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Its most recent report indicates seizures and surrenders of some 127 live birds, 125 live reptiles, 81 live fish, six live crabs, 708 plants, 401 turtle products and 375 butterfly specimens. That is what has been identified-goodness knows how many have slipped through the net.

During 1988-89 eight successful prosecutions were completed, including that of a West German citizen arrested at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport who was later charged with the illegal export of 27 Australian native birds and 11 Australian native reptiles. Unfortunately, a European tourist smuggling a few parrots out of the country is not a major problem. The major problem confronting our wildlife authorities is the international dealers who control networks involving tree climbers, trappers, middle men, bird breeders, dealers, pilots and boat owners. It is a complicated operation.

Australian fauna attracts a premium price on the international black market. This, together with our relative geographic isolation, makes illegal smuggling a very attractive proposition for the dishonest. A recent British publication called Animal Smugglers included an advertisement for a bird dealer in America who would supply any 10 pairs of Australian parrots delivered to your door for $100,000. Reports occasionally reach authorities of high powered speed boats which meet Indonesian vessels off the southern New South Wales coast in an effort to take fauna out of the country.

The effect of this illegal trade has been catastrophic. It is documented that one well known Australian collector amassed the largest illegal collection of Australian native eggs, which included 25,000 clutches. In areas of the Iron Range, which is frequented by smugglers, the eclectus parrot population has dropped by 80 per cent.

The Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce-TRAFFIC-has figures which indicate that a pair of Australian glossy black cockatoos can bring $50,000 on the international market, palm cockatoos fetch $25,000 a pair and golden shoulder parrots up to $10,000 a pair. The Major Mitchell, which is found in the Australian interior, can fetch $20,000 a pair, whilst kookaburras have been seen advertised in the United Kingdom recently for up to $1,600 each.

It is in this context that tougher measures are needed. It is also worth mentioning that in many cases the authorities simply do not have the manpower to appropriately police our vast continent. Modern fauna smugglers are equipped with expensive speed boats and light aircraft. Those caught at our airports represent only a very minor percentage. It seems to me that this trade is set up similarly to what we expect our illegal drug trade to be. In that context it is essential that all State governments receive the support of the Federal Government, beefing up the numbers of the authorities involved in trying to catch these illegal smugglers.

The Bill provides the Minister with greater discretion in relation to the export of some of our fauna species which are not endangered. In this context, the coalition would urge most strongly that consideration be given to allowing the export of native birds which are not threatened but which in some cases have bred in plague proportions. In particular, I refer to the great sulphur-crested cockatoo, the galah, the little corella and the long-billed corella.

In some parts of our country farmers are unable to sow their summer crops and may have difficulty in sowing winter crops because of the problems which these birds cause. They are notorious for taking the seed off the ground before it has germinated. In some areas they defoliate and ring-bark native trees to the extent that they kill them. I am sure my colleague Senator Panizza would attest seriously to the effect that some of these native birds, in plague proportions, would have on his wheat sowing.

The situation at present is that farmers must resort to a variety of less than successful methods to control the effect these birds have on crops. Explosive scare guns, the carbide or gas operated scare guns, high pitched sounds, scarecrows and various mechanical devices have all been used with little or no success. Although I know that in my own State one of our talkback radio personalities who has since retired, Sue Becker, was used in a vineyard quite effectively to scare off birds that were attacking some of the wine grapes down there. Nevertheless, it seems that one--

TALK.START.PARA: —I can think of a few people in here who would be pretty effective!

—The Minister is probably right. However, one method which appears to be successful in controlling the effect that these native birds can have is poison, but I am sure that we would all agree that it is a very distasteful method by which to control the birds. There is no doubt that many of these birds exist in plague proportions. However, poison is one of those methods which is unable to discriminate between species.

SPEECH.PARA: Another method which is used by farmers is netting. Under this system a decoy bird and some grain is used to attract, in some cases, many thousands of birds. When the net is triggered it folds over the top of the birds and traps them. The question then is what to do with the birds. Unfortunately, at this stage the options are pretty limited. They can be clubbed to death, stamped on or gassed. I think we would all agree that that is a wanton waste of a natural resource.

The coalition believes, and surely commonsense dictates, that it would be far better for these birds, which are in demand overseas, to be sold in a regulatory fashion. This would provide those in the rural community with a much needed boost to their income and would, at the same time, significantly detract from the markets available to the illegal operators. I guess in some ways it is a bit like the proposition put from time to time that drug addicts should be provided with drugs free of charge to reduce the scarcity of a particular item. Obviously, the release of these birds on the world market would have an effect on the price obtained for them overseas, but it is likely that this industry could generate many millions of dollars in overseas earnings. If such an industry were taxed, the Government and the general Australian community would also be winners.

Surely it is ludicrous that farmers are allowed to kill certain species of native birds but are not allowed to sell them for profit. The Minister has argued that ultimately research will provide a way of controlling the bird menace, but to date this has been less than effective. Procedures already exist whereby these birds could be exported because we are already allowed to export non-native birds from Australia.

The export regulations involved in this industry are very rigid. Exporters must be certified for quarantine purposes. Importers also must be certified. The exporter must have a Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora licence issued by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service at a cost of $40. All birds exported by this method are inspected at several stages during transport and the cages and feeding requirements are all very strictly regulated.

It would be far more pleasant for birds to be taken out of their country in this manner than to be injected with a tranquilliser, bound with tape and placed in a narrow tube, as is often the practice of smugglers as I mentioned earlier. It is difficult to obtain figures, but the most generally accepted one is that 90 per cent of birds smuggled out of the country are dead before they arrive at their destination. I guess that is one of the reasons why they become so expensive.

In 1976 an all-party committee made up of members of the House of Representatives recommended a relaxation of the total export controls on the type of native fauna to which I have referred. I should stress once again that we are not talking about endangered species but, rather, those species that can be found in abundance and which would be far better off in the control of wealthy overseas owners than being gassed or clubbed to death. The proposal to allow the export of these types of birds is also in agreement with the ideals of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, something about which I am sure Senator Coulter will have something to say in his contribution. More than 100 countries, including Australia, are signatories to this agreement which operates under the auspices of the United Nations environment program.

Naturally, such a proposal would arouse some criticism from animal welfare groups. I understand that the RSPCA is currently opposed to the export of live birds and animals unless it is a direct transfer between public utilities such as zoos. The RSPCA believes that the most humane method of control is by gas. Surely even the RSPCA can see that it would be far preferable to export these birds alive than to have them gassed to death.

Despite the protestations of the Minister, it is clear that the problems faced by our primary producers certainly will not go away. I am sure we are all too aware of the problems that face our beleaguered wheat growers. To allow these birds to be trapped by licensed collectors would certainly provide a new source of income to our farmers. In this respect the Bill obviously has its failings. I know that we on this side of the House are disappointed that the Government has not been prepared to be more proactive on this issue.

The next major area which I wish to address concerns the disastrous effect which the introduction of some overseas species of flora and fauna has had on our own local ecology. As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, I have recently been associated with a report on the effect of large feral animals on parts of the Northern Territory-in particular, sensitive areas such as Kakadu. It is a pity that Senator Burns, who was in the chair earlier and who is Chairman of our Committee, will not be participating in this debate because I think he would agree with me that we have seen plenty of evidence of the effects of the introduction of overseas species into Australia.

I will just mention some of the feral animals that have been introduced into Australia over the last couple of hundred years and the effect they have had not just on agriculture but also on our whole way of life. In particular, I refer to the effect that buffaloes introduced from Indonesia have had on the Kakadu area. I guess that Senator Collins has tracked plenty of them around there in his time.

TALK.START.PARA: —And shot plenty of them too.

—Right. They have had the effect of spreading brucellosis and tuberculosis among local cattle in the Top End. Quite frankly, I was amazed to see the effect they have had on the area, but since they have been shot out and reduced in numbers that area has recovered. I think it shows that mother nature is quite prepared to regenerate areas of land that have been affected in this way. I just hope that the Government will continue to fund the BTEC program in the Top End because I think that, from the tourism aspect and also that of local Aboriginals who have their own protected areas and disease free buffaloes which provide them with meat, it is essential that the program be continued.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have to tell you, Mr Deputy President, what effect the introduction of rabbits had in Australia. I think it is there for everybody to see. They have probably been the biggest curse on this country that we have ever known. I must say that the methods we have used to try to eradicate rabbits with poison and myxomatosis are distasteful even to me as a primary producer. I do not think anybody feels very comfortable with the methods we have used to try to eradicate rabbits. I must say that they are a pretty hardy species because they still survive in huge numbers. I think that a former Whip in the Senate, Bernie Kilgariff, would attest to the effect that rabbits are having on his station south of Alice Springs. When we were up there the evidence we heard was that there were something like 90,000 rabbits in his area. The effect they have on our land through erosion is quite immense.

I also do not have to remind the Senate of the effect of the importation of starlings. They are often referred to as the rats of the sky. People like myself-originally I was a fruit grower-and the wine producers of this country would attest to the huge cost of starlings even today. The cost that they bring to primary industry is certainly something we can do without.

During the evidence we had on the effect of large feral animals in northern Australia, it was quite interesting to note the effect of brumbies, or whalers as they are sometimes called, on the native flora and fauna of central Australia. In fact, evidence showed that since brumbies have increased in numbers in central Australia they have been responsible for wiping out 50 species of native flora and fauna over the last couple of decades. This evidence was given to us by a conservation group with good credentials in Alice Springs.

I will mention briefly some other well known animal imports into Australia that we could do without. I do not think I have to tell you, Mr Deputy President, of the effect of cane toads. Their numbers are still increasing. Even though they were introduced into this country legally, it just shows what can happen when the authorities do not look ahead and do their homework on the effect that some of these introduced species can have on our country. Camels, donkeys, goats, foxes and carp are just a few others that, without going into any great detail, have all affected Australia to a great extent one way or another. In fact, when we were taking evidence on the effect of large feral animals in the Northern Territory, one of the conclusions that we came to, and I quote from the report, was:

On the basis of evidence presented during the inquiry, the Committee is left in no doubt that feral animals pose a major problem. In particular, horses, buffalo and other large feral animals have a significant adverse effect on the environment of the Northern Territory. This manifests itself in degradation of the landscape and destruction of vulnerable Australian species of flora and fauna. Feral animals also have the potential to exacerbate problems arising from the introduction of exotic diseases.

We made quite a few recommendations on this point. I am not going to go into them because that is a story for another day. I will give some idea of the population of these animals that came into Australia quite innocently. In the early days, camels were brought in to transport goods through central Australia when no other form of transport was available. Donkeys were also brought in for that reason. Goats were introduced into Australia by the mariners of the early days as a food source. They are now in plague proportions. God knows why foxes were introduced into Australia. I guess they were for the landed gentry to go chasing with their hounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fox hunting.
—Fox hunting, yes.
—Some of your forebears.

—Some of my forebears; that is fine. I guess they were also some of Senator Coulter's forebears. The introduction of carp into our waterways is another disaster that we can look back on with little pride. Interestingly enough, when we talk about the culling of feral animals in the Northern Territory-and I know that Senator Collins is terribly interested in this-even considering the millions of dollars that have been spent and the vast amount of work that has gone into eradicating buffalo in the Top End, there is still estimated in Arnhem Land, Darwin, Katherine and Tennant Creek to be a population of some 108,000 buffalo. In Tennant Creek, Alice Springs and the Simpson Desert, camels have risen to the reasonable figure of 11,000. We have something like 80,000 donkeys in the Top End. I remember hearing evidence given to us by a landowner in the Victoria River district who said that station owners had eradicated 80,000 donkeys but within two years they still had 80,000 donkeys. So they are quite prolific breeders. The population of feral horses is estimated at something like 150,000, even though many of them are being shot and processed at Peterborough in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I might have gone on a little too long about this, but I am trying to make the point that we have to be very careful about the introduction of certain species into Australia. Whilst I have quoted plenty of examples of what has happened and the many millions of dollars that it has cost the producers of livestock and agricultural products in this country, which they could do without, one wonders what would happen in future if we had the introduction of wolves, for instance. They could bring rabies into Australia, which would be a horrendous problem. One also wonders what effect foot and mouth disease or swine fever would have on the feral pig population.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bad enough with high unemployment without these things.

—I do not know whether Senator Baume has heard of mad cow disease in the UK, but it would be an absolute disaster if that managed to get into our cattle population. Recently in Tasmania-my home State-we were so concerned about the effects of a disease that could be introduced with goldfish and decimate out agriculture industry. Goldfish have been banned from importation into Tasmania. It just shows that the most innocent of imports could have a disastrous effect on Australia unless we are vigilant.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see that the Government, after quite some delay, has introduced this Bill into the Senate to increase the penalties for those illegal exporters of our native animals and to increase the fines and sentences on those people wishing to introduce imported species into this country. We have to be ever-vigilant in this vast country of ours to make sure that those disasters of the past, caused by those particular animals that have cost this country so dearly not only in monetary terms but also in their effect on our natural environment, do not recur.

If ever foot and mouth disease gets into the wild pig population in the Northern Territory, I do not know how we will cope. I know that the authorities have made emergency plans, but it would be an absolute disaster for this country. I believe it is most important that we support any efforts by the Government to increase penalties and vigilance on not only the export of wildlife in this country but also the introduction of other species into this country. Therefore, it is essential that we support this legislation. I support previous speakers from this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this relatively trivial Bill-the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1991. I will make some more remarks about that in a moment. Firstly, I wish to pick up on a few remarks by Senator Calvert. I am reminded of the remarks about motes in eyes and not noticing the logs in eyes. That is the context in which I will be speaking about the trivial nature of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Calvert seems to be suggesting to us that we should somehow exploit the exportation of our native wildlife for profit, yet most of his speech was devoted to the dangers of importing exotic species into this country. I remind him that many of our parrot species, to which he drew our attention, carry psittacosis. I am sure that many other countries would not like to have psittacosis spread through their wildlife by the export of our parrots. I remind him that we have exported species of eucalypts to many countries and these have been extremely damaging on the native flora of those countries. The leaf litter under eucalypts has been extremely damaging throughout the Middle East and parts of Africa. I would certainly be extremely careful about the suggestion that we should export our wildlife, either flora or fauna, simply for profit without considering very carefully that we may be doing to other countries what some of our forebears did to Australia by introducing exotic species here.

I return to the mote and the log; to the point that this legislation, while it is entirely acceptable to the Australian Democrats, is really addressing a minuscule problem in relation to wildlife protection. The Democrats are of the view that this legislation simply does not address the fundamental problems facing our wildlife. Hopefully, in the next few weeks we will be introducing a much more comprehensive private member's Bill to address those very serious problems. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), in her second reading speech stated that we are:

. . . wearing away the fabric of the intricate biological web that sustains life on this planet. The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 is part of a global network of legislation, with the ultimate objective to ensure that our utilisation of wildlife and ecosystems is ecologically sustainable.

Without wishing to understate the importance of this legislation, I simply state that the Minister must be kidding if she thinks that the Wildlife Protection Bill shows that the Government is ensuring:
. . . that our utilisation of wildlife and ecosystems is ecologically sustainable.

Australia, like nearly every continent on earth, is suffering a major crisis in the loss of biological diversity. This current Australian Government, instead of trying to deal seriously with this most fundamental and irreversible of problems, is underfunding conservation programs in this country to a laughable extent; proposing to introduce resource security legislation which will almost certainly push many hundreds of species closer to extinction; continuing to support the destruction of the world's tropical rainforests by allowing the importation of tropical timber into Australia; and refusing to accept its constitutional responsibilities to protect our natural environment through threatened species and native vegetation legislation.

Just this afternoon with the introduction of the Budget we have seen a trifling amount of money allocated in the area of wildlife protection. Controlling the import and export of wildlife is an important issue, but this legislation does not address the fundamental problems with the management of our wildlife and our natural environment.

The world is being progressively impoverished by the loss and degradation of its most fundamental living resources: its genes, species, habitats and ecosystems. This loss of the planet's living richness is both wrong and dangerous. It is wrong because we should accept that all species have a right to exist, as the United Nations General Assembly stated when it adopted the World Charter for Nature in 1982. It is dangerous because the world's environmental systems are humanity's life support mechanisms and we do not know which components are key to maintaining their essential integrity. Professor Michael Archer from the University of New South Wales describes humanity's destruction of its life support systems most graphically. He argues:

. . . we have to book ourselves into the same league as the comet that may have struck the earth and obliterated half of the vertebrates from the world 65 million years ago. We are that sort of catastrophe. We are an extincting force, the like of which the world has never seen before.
A British ecologist has put it just as graphically when, in relation to man's destruction of nature, he said that it was the:
. . . greatest setback to life's abundance and diversity since the first flickerings of life almost 4 billion years ago.

It is incredibly arrogant for homo sapiens in 1991 to think that they know enough about the operation of the natural world that, in any sense, it will work better or even as well with more and more species being removed through humanity's uncaring exploitation.

Some scientists predict that if present trends continue up to 25 per cent of the world's species will be lost in the next several decades, accompanied by an equally alarming degradation of habitats and ecosystems. Of course, a large part of that will be through the clearing of tropical rainforests-something with which we will be dealing legislatively on Thursday and upon which this Government has so far failed to take any action.

The problem of species extinction is not restricted to overseas countries. Indeed, European Australia has one of the worst records of species extinction of any country. Our extinction rates are still unacceptably high even today. In the past 200 years, since the settlement of this continent by Europeans, Australia is known to have lost 30 large and visible animals and 100 plants. Professor Harry Recher from the University of New England notes:

Recognition of the impact of European settlement on the Australian landscape and its flora and fauna has been slow to emerge. Most Australians view the continent as vast, unspoiled and underpopulated. Yet in historical times, no other continent has experienced the massive changes in the distribution and abundance of such a large proportion of its vertebrate fauna as has Australia. In 200 years Europeans have recast the evolutionary biogeography of the continent.

And this appalling record is continuing. Australia has an estimated 111 animals and nearly 1,000 plants that are currently threatened with extinction. It is against that sort of record that we are dealing this evening with what I described earlier as a trivial piece of legislation.

But unlike other nations the great tragedy is that most Australians do not even know about the wildlife we are destroying. Australians know more about the plight of the African elephant or the Bengal tiger than they do about the thylacine, the bilby, or the quoll. That indeed is a great tragedy which we must redress urgently if we are to gain community support in saving our wildlife.

I interpolate here, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is a peculiar anomaly that in Australia one needs no legal permission whatsoever to own an exotic animal-a cat, dog, donkey or many of those animals which you mentioned in your speech earlier-yet one requires permission to own a native animal. In 1990, Recher and Lee noted:

Of the 1600 species of terrestrial vertebrates, nearly 300 are considered endangered. Seventeen mammals, three birds, and one species of lizard are known to have become extinct since European settlement in 1788.
In just over 200 years we have destroyed forever 20 mammals that occurred nowhere else on earth. That represents a loss, on average, of one mammal every 10 years.

Many people think that the great mammal extinctions occurred in the late 1800s and that by the early 1900s most of the extinctions had already occurred. This is not so. Species extinctions have been occurring since then and are more than likely to continue to occur because of the inaction of the current Government. Again, I interpolate that very often the seeds of species extinction are sown many years-sometimes decades-before the last animal actually disappears simply because of the change to the habitat of those animals.

We only need to lose one mammal in the next 10 years for us to retain the extinction rate that has in the past given us by far the worst mammal extinction record of any society in the history of humans on this earth. It is an outrage that a nation whose high standard of living is dependent almost entirely on the natural environmental assets of this continent can have such little regard to its continued health and show such indifference to the plight of many unique native species who share this continent with us. These extinctions have not occurred as a result of trade in wildlife, as the Minister's second reading speech might have us believe. They have occurred because of far greater problems with the way in which we have managed, and to a large extent still manage, our natural environment and the resources contained within it.

To address the real causes of extinction satisfactorily, it is necessary to turn to the principles of population ecology and to the historical record. On past debates in this chamber, it would not be misplaced to dwell a little on some of these. Three factors affect the extinction of species. Firstly, extinction is a complex process which occurs over many years; it is not simply the death of the last individual of a species. As I indicated a moment ago, the processes which lead to the final loss of that last individual are very often irrevocably put in place decades before that last animal dies.

Secondly, there are two cause and effect factors which determine the process of extinction-the deterministic and the random. Deterministic factors are those which have predictable effects on a population, such as habitat loss. Random factors, such as drought, fire or floods are unpredictable in occurrence and consequence. Both affect the extinction process. The smaller the population size, the more susceptible it is to extinction from chance events. This bears fairly and squarely on the issue of resource security legislation, which we are told will be introduced in this place and which will see many of our remnant forests divided into small areas, making them extremely susceptible to those random events which will see the total extinction of the species contained in them.

The third factor in the extinction process occurs at the level of populations and not at the level of species. Because of this, conservation strategies must focus on managing for population viability and not simply on just saving a few animals in zoos. Recher and Lee note:

The impact of European settlement (on terrestrial fauna) has been greatest on mammals and birds. In the 200 years since the colony was established in 1788 at Port Jackson, 17 species of terrestrial mammals, three taxa of birds and the Adelaide blue-tongue lizard are known to have become extinct.
Eight species of mammals formerly occurring on the mainland survive only on isolated, small offshore islands.

Many people think that the great extinctions of our wildlife and their habitats occurred in the very early days of European settlement and that the damage has largely already been done. This view is simply untrue. The rates of extinction on this continent are as rapid now as they were at any time in the past. Recher and Lee state:

In describing the decline and extinction of the Australian terrestrial vertebrate fauna, we are not describing changes over 200 years of settlement. Instead, most events occurred within 20 or 30 years of an area being settled. For most of the continent the changes described occurred within this century. The impact of Europeans on the Australian environment is not measured in centuries, but in decades. This pattern is now being repeated in the south-west and north-west of the continent as settlement of these regions intensifies.

It is the ground-dwelling mammals in the size range of 35 grams to 5,000 grams which have been most affected by European settlement. In the arid and semi-arid regions few mammals in this critical size range survive. The record from our forests is a little better, but predictions are that extinctions in these areas are likely in the near future. Apart from the thylacine and the eastern quoll, no mammals have as yet been lost from forest habitats. However, many species have declined in abundance and there are many regional extinctions because about 50 per cent of our forests have been cleared and populations are now fragmented. That, as I indicated earlier, bears very much on the question of resource security legislation. Destroying species and destroying habitats for short term economic gain is about as sensible as burning a Picasso to cook dinner. As quoted previously, the Minister said:

The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 is part of a global network of legislation, with the ultimate objective to ensure that our utilisation of wildlife and ecosystems is ecologically sustainable.

Let us look at the magnitude of the problem and how this Government's record stands up to this rhetoric from the Minister. Half of Australia's soils are affected by erosion and/or salination. That is a very significant factor in the extinction of species-habitat change. Over four million hectares of pastoral inland are on the verge of becoming perpetual desert. Australia's soils have been mined of their nutrients and organic matter. The scale of the disaster is unprecedented. Viewed in this context, the decline of the continent's vertebrate fauna is almost meaningless; the extinction of species becomes a symptom of far more pervasive changes to the land. We have no idea of the number of species-the small species, the bacteria and the other less obvious species-that live in the soil and upon which the integrity of the soil's ecology is based.

As ecologists we would view the decline of Australia's fauna as a symptom of more serious events and seek to remedy the problem by correcting the underlying causes and not by treating the symptoms. It is not simply the large and obvious animals; it is the underlying change in the infrastructure which supports the whole ecology.

The Federal Government proudly boasts an endangered species program of $2m per annum, which we have just seen increased to $5m in today's Budget. That $2m represents 0.002 per cent of the Federal Budget. This Government is prepared to commit only 0.002 per cent of its Budget to saving Australia's endangered heritage. A spokesman for the World Wide Fund for Nature has described this level of funding as laughable. It has stated that this level of funding is perhaps one-thousandth of what we need in the coming decades. The cash required is enormous. To find an appropriate control for things such as the fox might take 10 years, and it might take tens of millions of dollars for that control to be applied. Unless we as Australians make a commitment now to start to fix the fundamental problems with the management of our natural environment, we will never solve the problem and our extinctions will continue to occur. Michael Kennedy from the World Wide Fund for Nature in Australia has stated:

. . . the amount of $2 million per year for the first two years of the Endangered Species Program is laughable and a disgrace, and it won't save species. It will not serve to stop the growing list of species under threat, and it will simply serve to watch the list grow longer; it's just not enough.
He is referring there to the fact that that amount of money is just about enough to catalogue and report to the Australian population what is going on, but not to address the underlying problems.

The Federal Government's funding level represents less than 13c a year for each Australian to save our irreplaceable heritage. This Government spent more on landscaping the grounds around this Parliament House than it has spent on saving species in Australia in the past three years. The funding level and the Government's Budget spending priorities are shameful, and it will stand condemned by future generations if it lets one more species slip into extinction because it did not care enough. There is a desperate need for government policy to reflect a holistic approach to the protection of biodiversity through maintenance of habitat and sustainable land use practices, rather than relying on the ecologically simplistic notion of trying to save this species or that one, or trying to stop the export of 10 gang gang cockatoos, as was mentioned in the Minister's speech.

A major problem with the funding of environmental programs in Australia is the lack of certainty and continuity of funding. This leads to programs being devised which do not take a long term perspective and, instead, rely on achieving quantifiable results in the short term. As a nation we were able to plan a 25-year Snowy Mountains scheme to help improve our economic well-being, but it appears that a far simpler task of providing funding certainty to repair our natural environment cannot be done. That, of course, is a nonsense. The problem is not the inability to provide certainty; it is the lack of political will to do so.

The result of funding programs year by year is that designing research programs is easier and likely to be more favourably treated than actual on-the-ground recovery work, because after a one- or two-year program something physical, such as a paper or a study, can be produced to justify the expenditure. This is not to denigrate research as a valuable component of endangered species programs- indeed, much more needs to be spent in this area alone-but it does highlight the desperate need to design longer term conservation and recovery strategies, and the only way this will occur is if long term funding is guaranteed.

The Democrats call on the Government to consider seriously, in consultation with the community, conservation, industry, farm, fishing and forestry groups, a 200-year Australian conservation plan which contains aims, objectives, goals and action plans and funding targets for at least 10 years in advance for this plan.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I advise honourable senators that I have been informed that cars will be at the Senate side this evening. It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —For three weeks in July and August, I was a member of an Opposition delegation that very happily visited seven countries in Latin America. Tonight, I wish briefly to refer to our observations and the very high success of our visit. I have prepared a rather brief summary of the various meetings and other events that occurred during our visit to these seven countries. I will refer to it a little later in my speech. I assure the Senate that I will confine my remarks to a relatively short compass because we are on the adjournment debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There were three Liberal members of Parliament who composed the delegation: Senator Hill, the Opposition foreign affairs spokesman; Mr Moore MP, a former Liberal Government Minister for business; and myself, as the Chairman of the Opposition's international relations task force or, in other terms, the Chairman of the foreign affairs and defence committee of the Opposition.

We visited Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Peru, Venezuela, Colombia and Mexico. Why did we go to Latin America and why at this time? I have, for example, visited Asia perhaps 20 times-10 times before I came to the Senate and 10 times since I have been in the Senate. It is well known that Australia's major trading partners are in Asia. Many of us have travelled in Europe; many of us have travelled in North America; some, such as the President of the Senate, have a very close personal knowledge of Africa. But I do not know anybody in the Senate or in the House of Representatives who has a careful knowledge of Latin America. I speak of all the countries from Mexico through Central America and the whole South American continent.

I must be honest and say that in all my 46 years very few Australians have spoken to me about their visits to any of the Latin American countries. I do not know anyone in Parliament who has expounded at any length about our economic opportunities in Latin America. I know of individual honourable senators including you, Mr Deputy President, who have made particular visits to some countries-in your case, to observe the Chilean elections, in the case of a few other members of Parliament to be part of an IPU delegation and so on.

This was the first time for a long period that there had been a conscious, well prepared, deliberate reconnaissance by a political party to explore and to come up with its own first-hand evaluations of the opportunities for Australia-especially in economic terms, but in the broader foreign affairs agenda as well-with the republics of Latin America. In part, the same reasons that led us to go led Senator Loosley, me and our colleagues on the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, to recommend to the Senate that the Committee take on a reference-which it is currently in the midst of-of looking at Australia's relations with the Latin American countries.

There are three particular reasons why this comes together in 1991. We have really only just woken up to the political events of the last two years that have seen a broad return of democracy to all of the countries of the region. Of course, in most countries there had been long traditions of democracy but-notoriously in Chile until last year, and in other countries-there had been dictatorships of the Right, military coups or even populist and quite counter-productive regimes of the Left.

The first alerting situation was the return of democracy to Latin America. Had there not been the election in Chile that led to the new democratic government from March of last year, we might not have undertaken this visit. Secondly, there has been a quite remarkable conversion of the governments of Latin America to market economics; a rejection of the Left; a rejection of socialism and a full embracing of what we in Australia would call an attempt to be internationally competitive. There has been a real attempt to get inflation down to manageable levels, to cut tariffs to become more and more involved in free trade, and actually to have the substance of international competitiveness as the basis for increased trade and increased economic prosperity for each of the countries.

Mexico comes to mind with President Salinas's quite abrupt turning around of his own party in this direction. Also, there was the wholehearted way in which the governments of Chile and Uruguay have embraced market economics, the quite dramatic election of the Fujimori Government last year in Peru and the whole new wave of market orientated economic policies that have swept that country in the last 12 months.

The second broad reason for our being interested is that we perceive the Latin American economies to be open to the world and increasingly able to have an economic partnership with Australia. In fact, whilst many talk about Australia being in danger, through bad economic policies, of going down the `Argentine road', I came back from Latin America thinking about the very real danger-Senator Michael Baume will appreciate this-that the Latin American countries may, if we do not get on a little more quickly with economic reform, both macro-economic and micro-economic, be saying, `Beware, lest we in Latin America go down the Australian road'. I hope there will never be any real substance to such an anecdote because in this country we desperately need to go down the path of freer trade, market economics and genuine macro-economic and micro-economic reform ourselves.

The third, and perhaps minor, matter is that we now have a transport link between Australia and Latin America-especially the very serviceable flight from Sydney through Auckland, on the South Pole route, to Buenos Aires. This is an arrangement between Aero Lingus and Qantas which, I believe, ought to be expanded. There is also a link through Los Angles with the middle American States, and a link directly with San Diego and Chile which flies through French Polynesia and Easter Island. The links exist and Australians-politicians and businessmen alike-can get on the flights and be there before the night falls. It is possible for Australians to include Latin America in a convenient transport link.

One of the reasons why I was a member of the delegation was the Senate inquiry. The Committee has had its first hearing and has already received some 90 submissions from a wide variety of Australian and Latin American interests. We hope to conclude that inquiry by the end of this year with a full report and a full set of recommendations leading on from the evaluations we make of Australia's opportunities in relation to the Latin American republics.

In the past, as I say, this area of the world has been largely neglected by Australia. There is one exception. In 1961 when McEwen was trade Minister he urged Senator Gorton, as he then was, to lead a delegation of parliamentarians to Latin America. That delegation came back with its report. In 1962, a very large group-I think it comprised about 50 members of every type of industry, bank and business in Australia-went there for three or four months toting contracts, coming back with concluded deals built upon the foundations that had been opened up by the politicians, and trying to give meaning to some of the emerging shipping links with ports on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of the continent. This flourished for some years. Unfortunately, even before the end of the 1960s, these activities had not amounted to much. We then had the political and economic turmoil that distracted all of us until this past year or two.

We have more than economic relations to consider as matters of mutual interest between Australia and the Latin American republics. We have a very genuine concern on disarmament and arms control. Mexico is not the only country that shares Australia's interests in this area. In terms of the environment, there is a major international environment conference in Brazil next year. We have shared interests in Antarctica. We also have a common interest to eliminate narcotic trafficking in the world in terms of both demand and supply.

I have noted the seven countries that we visited. Of course, I should mention why we did not visit Brazil on this occasion. Brazil is Australia's largest trading partner. It has by far the largest population-about 150 million people-has by far the largest land area in Latin America, and has an enormously developed infrastructure around Sao Paulo, the former capital of Rio de Janeiro and the new capital of Brazilia, which are all important decision making points not only for Brazil but for the whole continent.

Given that we had only three weeks and that we intended to visit seven countries in a very hardworking way, we felt that to visit for just a few days would not do service to our relationship with Brazil, and we are intent upon seeing a second Liberal and National Party group of parliamentarians travel to Brazil and perhaps Paraguay and Bolivia next year so that there can be a proper concentration on our coming to grips with opportunities in Brazil.

I wish to refer to about half a dozen particular recommendations. I note that our current level of trade with the Latin American region is 1 per cent; more precisely, it represents 1.0 per cent of Australia's export trade and 1.4 per cent of Australia's imports. I believe that the opportunity exists for this trade to multiply to between 3 per cent and 5 per cent of Australia's total trade by the end of this decade. That is a rather bold statement and it means that there will be a substantial increase in the economic relations between Australia and these republics. I may be underestimating the potential or what will actually be achieved.

I still hold the view that the majority of our trade and economic relations will be with Asia. However, we must follow up this capacity for increased economic relations with Latin America. I believe that we should map out this increased capacity for growing economic relations by spelling out the items of export appropriate to be pursued in each country. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should have an annually revised economic relations strategy with each country in Latin America. It should be openly determined in consultation with the countries themselves, not a secret or conspiratorial plan, with an open set of goals that is objective about the needs of those economies and about the strengths and potential exports from Australia. This set of strategies should involve at least 10 or 12 of the most developed countries of the region.

I was admirably impressed by Ambassador Baker, our Ambassador in Mexico, giving priority-it appeared, his first priority-in a very practical way to improving Mexican-Australian economic relations. In many countries that I have visited it seems that our representatives, our ambassadors and our other staff in embassies, are mostly intent upon the full range of what we would call the foreign affairs agenda. It is refreshing to see an Australian embassy and an ambassador single-mindedly giving priority to Australia's economic relations and, indeed, to an explicit Australian national interest. I make no apology for talking about an Australian national interest. It must be pursued openly and in conjunction with the mutual interests of the other countries which are in a bilateral relationship with us.

I sometimes gained the impression during my recent visit that economic relations are left to the Austrade officer, a person who is generally rather junior in the array of staff, even if very experienced and highly skilled to do the work involved. It is usually left to an officer rather than being fully embraced by the whole team in our Australian embassy in a particular country. That is not the case in Mexico and I wish it were not the case in every other country in the region. Each ambassador should have an annually revised economic relations brief to pursue Australia's interest in the mutual economic cooperation that Australia has with each of those host countries. I speak not only of trade but also of investment and of airline and shipping links.

There are three countries, in particular, that offer the most substantial potential for Australia's renewed economic relations: Mexico, Chile and Columbia. I say this, aware of the fact that currently our largest trading partnership is with Brazil and that Argentina is, in its own way, bursting with opportunities for Australia's investment requiring in-country management by Australians.

But why Mexico, Chile and Columbia? They are all highly developed economies with impressive recent years of growth. They have open economies, market oriented and ready to cement freer trade relationships with Australia. They are disciplined economies in reasonably good order. They are economies directed to flourish with international competition. They are not inward looking, but genuinely outward looking to the world.

All three-Mexico, Columbia and Chile-have Pacific coasts. They have ports that are just across the water from our eastern coast. They are very aware of their own Pacific orientation and they want to develop their economic relations with Australia and beyond Australia to Asia. They are interested to join the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation and other Pacific and Asian associations in which Australia has a major part. By highlighting these countries, I do not wish to underestimate Venezuela, Brazil, Uruguay, or even Peru. They each have their own specific opportunities. As I outlined earlier, we should develop our expanded economic relations with all of them.

Let me address Mexico, in particular. I put it to the Australian Government and to Senator Gareth Evans and Dr Blewett in particular, that we urgently negotiate with Mexico a free trade bilateral agreement of the type that Mexico has already concluded with Chile, and that this Australia-Mexico agreement be in place before the North America free trade agreement is concluded by March 1992, and certainly before it is ratified by the two congresses by September 1992.

In conjunction with this development, we should in turn sponsor Mexico to be admitted as a member of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, process. I believe that Mexico should be a member of APEC. Already the United States and Canada are members. These countries will be in a free trade agreement very shortly. I believe that Mexico should be as well. Yes, I am suggesting that we conclude this this year, and that we do it urgently. Our embassies in Canberra and in Mexico City are well equipped to map this out, and the Deputy Foreign Minister, Rozental, is coming here in October. I believe that a trade agreement can be achieved this year.

Australian trade prospects with Mexico are enormous in the areas of coal, uranium, dairy products, agricultural equipment, food processing, mining and so on. They are all very real prospects. If we do not take up such opportunities this year, we may find that, against Mexico's intention, the North American free trade agreement somehow cuts us out. I greatly envy Chile's already established free trade agreement with Mexico. Australia can have the same agreement.

I now turn to Chile. Australia has already invested up to $US2 billion in Chile. We have already begun to invest in that country in a significant way, but much more can be done. There are actually many active Australians pursuing these opportunities, but they need to be encouraged. One of the gains or consolations of the Pinochet period-and I reject the Pinochet period entirely: its rightist dogma, its rejection of democracy, its military methods and all of the abuses of that period, which have been highlighted in the report given to the President early this year-was that by some good chance that regime implemented the economic policies of the so-called Chicago boys. They were, in fact, open, well-disciplined economic policies, and they have left Chile in very good economic shape.

Chile and Australia understand each other. Chile has high economic objectives, and Australia should establish a strong partnership across the Pacific with Chile. I also believe that Chile's admission to APEC should be fully explored as our own bilateral economic relations increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to this brief speech?

—I am sorry; I will try to summarise what I have to say. I now refer to Colombia. Colombia has enormous natural resources but, more than that, Colombia also has a high educational attainment, good management skills and entrepreneurship. I am struck by this entrepreneurship because, not only in Colombia but even in Venezuela, there are many Colombian managers of industry and other businesses. I believe that, as soon as Colombia can rid itself of the evil of drug trafficking and the small remaining amount of political terrorism in the hinterland, the sky will be the limit for Columbia. It will be a most prosperous country. Already it has phenomenal economic growth and very well-based economic policies. Colombia is crying out for Australian partnership in shared technology and direct investment, particularly in oil and gas but also in coal, cut flower production, petrochemicals and a very wide range of other products.

SPEECH.PARA: I also urge, and recommend to the Australian Government, that Australia establish a full embassy in Bogota as soon as the narcotic drug and terrorist violence is more reasonably under control. Great progress has been made in recent years. In fact, in Catagena on the Caribbean coast we were able to walk around everywhere without any protection whatsoever. In Bogota it is a different matter and in Medellin it is still a major problem. I believe that, given the economic capacity of Colombia, it should be the location of our next embassy in Latin America. In fact, we should probably establish that embassy next year.

In any event, in Bogota I have urged the establishment of an Australian-Colombian chamber of commerce, a process which should involve our Ambassador de Stoop; the honorary consul Cardenas; and Colombia's former Ambassador and my good friend, Dr Puerto. It ought to be led directly by young enterprising businessmen such as Mr Alberto Vargas, who has been regularly travelling to Australia for the last nine years and whose company sells half of all Australia's carpet backing in a country that sells more carpet per capita than any other in the world and a country that produces the wool that goes into those carpets. There are many other business interests in such a positive development.

I hasten to add that Australia's embassy in Venezuela should be retained. After all, Venezuela is the most affluent country per capita in the region and many economic opportunities exist for us, let alone the full foreign affairs agenda. However, I believe the embassy there should develop an explicit strategy with an economic interest as priority and then, quarter by quarter, monitor progress with that plan. Our experience since unhappily closing our embassy in Lima back in 1986 may prove to have been very short-sighted. It is too early to say yet whether the Fujimori reforms will bring some prosperity to the country, because the whole economy is still very fragile. If that prosperity does come, I think in a few years we will regret that we removed the embassy in Peru.

I now refer to the airlines. Qantas used to fly to Mexico City. I genuinely hope for and urge Qantas's return to Mexico City. Also I believe that Australia ought to get directly involved in the route to Santiago and Buenos Aires and an on-flight for Uruguayan businessmen from Buenos Aires to Montevideo. I believe that airlines can be expanded, and Australia has to take some initiatives in this area. I also think it is possible for some of these flights to go on to North America and Europe.

Finally, I cannot fail to mention the importance of continuing cooperation between Australia and the Latin American countries, particularly those that are members of the Cairns group in the present GATT round. Uruguay is our strongest ally in taking a hard line right to the bitter end in the negotiations that are yet to be concluded and in trying to bring some sense to Europe and North America in allowing free trade and fairness for our products to be sold on the world market. We have very close emotional and political ties because of our alliances in the GATT round, and we should build on that.

There are many other areas of evaluation and recommendation that I wish to refer to, but I will seek to incorporate those thoughts in the report of the Senate inquiry, which is still to be written. I conclude my speech by seeking leave to incorporate the remaining pages that I have prepared to save my speaking again tomorrow evening.
Leave granted.
