In Venezuela, we had a one-hour engaging meeting with President Carlos Andres Perez at the Miraflores Palace who undertook to positively support the forthcoming Venezuelan parliamentarian delegation visit to Australia and whose long political experience places him in a strong position to influence regional politics towards free trade and sounder economics; his Minister for Economic Planning and Coordination, Dr Miguel Rodriguez who especially met us on a Sunday morning and impressed us with his intelligent embrace of market-directed economic reform; and Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs Dr Rosaria Orellana-she struck me as a sophisticated practitioner who would happily build a growing relationship with Australia.

In Colombia unfortunately we missed meeting President Gaviria who I as a fellow Liberal had wanted to congratulate for his positive pursuit of economic reform and industrial development and for his skilful and successful progress to eliminate the cancer of narcotic drug trafficking and the violence of the now small minority of political terrorists. However, we met the politically astute and rising Liberal Minister for Economic Development, Dr Ernesto Samper who the next day was to be interlocutor with Ambassador Carla Hills in her visit to Bogota. We met Minister for Mines and Energy, Dr Luis-Fernando Vergara busy with vast prospects in oil, coal, minerals and gas and in energy infrastructure developments in all of which Australia could be an important partner. We were well received by Deputy Foreign Minister, the young Dr Rodrigo Pardo whose Ministry made excellent arrangements for our three-day visit through former Colombian Ambassador to Australia Dr Antonio Puerto and his soon successor and Colombia's most experienced diplomat, Mr Fernando Navas.

In Mexico we missed meeting President Carlos Salinas who had so successfully visited Australia a year ago. He was of course engaged in the last week of the Congressional election campaign, the ballot being 18 August, and in his regular Friday visits to the poor and remote villages of Mexico implementing his Solidarity program. However, we met his PRI party colleague Lic Roberta Lajous, who represented PRI President, Senator Colosio, and who is a dynamic and intelligent activist of the ``1988 generation'' that has supported the sweeping Salinas reforms of the past two years and for which the momentum is still growing. We met Deputy Foreign Minister, Mr Andres Rozental, whose comprehensive and authoritative grasp of detail is impressive and who will visit Australia in October. I hope he may be accompanied by Deputy Secretary, Ambassador Sandra Fuentes who admirably oversees our growing bilateral relations. Finally, I was delighted to meet for two hours with Attorney-General Ignacio Morales to discuss legal aspects of Mexico-Australia cooperation but much more profoundly some conceptual aspects of the nature of law, the human bases of legal relationships and his own personal appreciation of Mexican art and cultural roots especially in his own much loved Vera Cruz region.
2 Parliaments and parliamentarians

In all seven countries I was able to visit the Parliament buildings and in particular the two Chambers of each Congress, that is seven Senate Chambers and seven House of Representative Chambers. There is a charming and at times even beautiful distinctiveness about the rather baroque palatial Congress buildings that are among the most architecturally significant buildings in Buenos Aires, Montevideo, Santiago, Lima, Caracas, Bogota and Mexico City. I make an exception for the new Congress building remotely and rectangularly placed at Valparaiso by a previous regime. The Congress buildings are still alive with the inspirational memories of such independence heroes as Artigas, San Martine, Bolivar and Santander. In some countries parliamentary democracy has a long history but in most there have been during this century unfortunate suspensions under military regimes of the Right and populist but self-serving and deluded regimes of the Left. Today in every country Parliamentary Democracy is flourishing. Had this not been so then our inclination to make this visit would not have arisen. Of course, constitutionally, Parliaments in Latin America are more of the Washington than Westminster model with directly elected Executive Governments and a quite separately elected Congress as Legislature. Nevertheless parliamentarians both here and there have a great deal in common and we understood each other.

In Argentina, we attended a House of Representatives session and I was surprised to find the practice of remaining seated to give a speech. Senator Eduardo Menem, Peronist and brother of the President met us in his capacity as Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee. He enthusiastically defended the economic reform policies of the Government and Argentina's international bid for freer trade. We also met former President Alfonsin, cheerful but ageing, at the Radical Party headquarters.

In Uruguay, our tour of the Parliament building was a real highlight of Montevideo. The two chambers, especially the Senate are architecturally quite dramatic and the marble intricacies of the central assembly hall, the external frescoes and the uniquely elaborated classical pillars and statuary on the roof of the Congress are all very striking. Senator Abreu of the government Blanco Party, an intelligent and relaxed man, hosted a dinner for us, as he is Chairman of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee. Earlier we had met two Opposition Senators of his committee, one from the Colarado Party and the other Communist.

In Chile, one of our most memorable and positive conversations was our meeting with the Chairman of the House of Representatives, Mr Jose-Antonio Viera Gallo, a lawyer, formerly of the left and a leading member of the minority People's Democracy Movement which forms the coalition government with the Christian Democrats. Also we were admirably received by the enormously experienced President of the Senate, a Christian Democrat, Senator Gabriel Valdes and we discussed reconciliation in Chile's current political process. Senator Arturo Alessandri, an independent involved with the mining industry in the northern areas of Chile invited us to his own legal firm where he was enthusiastic about the Australian partnership with his country. In Valparaiso we met Vice President of the Senate, Beltran Urenda and former Minister and now appointed Senator Ronald McIntyre, both from the Right.

In Peru we visited both Chambers approached through elegant corridors decorated with the portraits of two centuries of Chairmen of the Representatives on the left side and Presidents of the Senate on the right side. Parliament was in recess but we met informally with elected Senator Belaunde, a young businessman whose father, as a former President of the Republic, held a Senate seat also.

In Venezuela the Parliament is adjacent to a busy shopping centre in Caracas. We met parliamentarians Dip. Julio Camino of the Government Party and Dip. Jose Martinez, an independent-the former I had earlier met in Canada, and the latter travelled by plane with us to the Leoni Dam beyond the Orinocco River. I was very interested to meet Sr Miguel A del Pozo, a Christian Democrat secretary of the Parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee.

In Colombia when I visited the Congress, the adjacent square was filled with schoolchildren, bands and soldiers departing on a celebration march through the city to inaugurate the day renaming the capital city ``Santa Fe de Bogota'', its original founding name. The Senate Chamber displayed a prominent painting of Bolivar and Santander after whom two provinces also are named. Interestingly the Standing Committees of the Senate have permanent meeting rooms which give the appearance of being used equally as much as the plenary Chamber itself. We attended a press conference in the Senate and visited the House of Representatives Chamber.

In Mexico for the seventh time in successive countries I sat in the Presiding Chair of the Senate, this time under the carved national emblem of eagle and snake. We were graciously received by the Grand Commission of the Senate (an executive which has Senate powers in between sessions) and on another evening the Grand Commission of the Chamber of Deputies. Parliamentarians of all parties were represented in our discussions, many of whom were keen to join the delegation to visit Australia later this year. In Mexico parliamentarians must retire at the end of their first term, although some go on to contest seats in the alternative Chamber. On one afternoon we attended a Congressional election meeting at the town of Zumpango.
3 Business leaders and Industry

In Argentina, the Australia-Argentine Chamber of Commerce met with us over breakfast at the Alvear Hotel and I was impressed with the President Carlos Bunge and his enthusiasm for Australian trade and joint ventures. Other business representatives including pasturalists, bankers, journalists and traders attended a splendid dinner hosted by the Australian Ambassador Bob Robertson. The Austrade officer, Mr Cesar Fernandez also advised us.

In Uruguay, our Friday evening dinner included Mr Pedro Nicolas Baridon, President of the Chamber of Industry and Mr Ernesto Carran, President of the Chamber of Commerce-both successful entrepreneurs with wide interests. Mr Baridon urged an improved airlink with Sydney including dedicated on-flights to Montevideo. On two successive days we happily met with Mr Daniel Supervielle, Board member of the Wool Secretariat and our guide to a prosperous estancia. At ``La Rabida'' we inspected dairy, beef, sheep and lucerne cropping where the pastures ended abruptly on the edge of the Rio de la Plata. We met members of the Charolais Society and noted that Mr Rodrigo Artagoveita and others will attend a Charolais meeting in Sydney next year.

In Chile a wide range of businessmen attended our welcoming lunch including the Australia-Chile Chamber of Commerce President from the forestry industry together with lawyers bankers and especially the mining industry. At the Australian reception at Hotel Plaza San Francisco we met representatives of BHP, Mr Isa Mines, Coca Cola, the Spanish Bank Banco Santander, the ANZ Bank and Comalco. We were happy to be advised by Austrade officer, Mr Guillermo Garcia whom I invited to tennis when he visits Australia later this year. In Vino del Mar we discussed shipping routes and capacities with ship agents, Ian Taylor and John Gray. We also were able to call on think-tank economists, Mr Christian Larroulet (one of the ``Chicago boys'') at the Institute of Liberty and Development, and Mr Joaquin Vial at the Centre for Economic Research in Latin America.

In Peru, no Australian businesses were brought to our attention although the opportunities for Australian involvement could be significant- in mining and energy, in food processing and in agricultural technology. Currently our largest export to Peru, by far, is barley.

In Venezuela, no Australian businesses were brought to our attention but Australian trade has doubled to A$40m in the last two years. There are prospects for Australia exporting mining equipment, food processing technology, agriculture technology (seeds and cattle) and telecommunications equipment as Venezuela's already prospering economy extends the development of abundant natural resources. We were able to fly beyond the Orinocco River one Saturday to tour the huge hydroelectric dam at Guri; current capacity 10,000 megawatts but becoming 18,000 megawatts when two subsidiary dams are completed by the end of the century. We also visited a pine plantation on the sandy plain north of Puerto Ordaz at Uverito.

In Colombia, I was greatly impressed by that country's magnificent prospects for natural resource development and industrial development. Already Colombia is the only Latin American country to have had positive real economic growth in all of the last twenty years. The economy is prosperous, broadly based and strengthened by comparatively high education standards and distinctively good local entrepreneurial and management skills. Coffee the traditional mainstay is now being overtaken by the wealth generated from oil, gas, coal, gold, emeralds, cut flowers, textiles and the products of the petrochemical industry. For example, most of Australia's carpet backing is imported from Colombia and about half of the cut-flower trade in the USA and Europe is based on Colombian exports. We visited glasshouses near Bogota to examine rose and carnation production and packaging; and in Cartagena and Bogota we visited polypropylene, PVC, plastic bioriented film, vinyl flooring, vinyl wallpaper, textiles, carpet backing and other related production plants. These industries have state of the art equipment with computer controls. We also visited in the seaside lowlands of the Magdalena River a new enterprise in shrimp farming currently producing about twenty million six-inch prawns each 3-month cycle. This development is building its own research technology in a specialised food market to serve the European and North American markets. At an evening reception in Bogota and on several other occasions we met the business entrepreneurs of Colombia. I gained the impression that as sound investors and managers they could teach many Australians a great deal about how to be internationally competitive and win overseas trade. The Colombian Government and the great majority of the Colombian people are determined to rid their country of the twin cancers of narcotic drug traders and minority political terrorists. In recent years great improvements have been won on both fronts. As soon as these evils may be eliminated Colombia will be a significant economic force not only in the region but internationally. (Finally, I add a footnote about the myth that Colombia's prosperity may be based n the 1980's drug trade. This myth is false. The drug trade based in remote areas of Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia was estimated last year to generate US$4B annually. One quarter of this amount finds its way back to the local economies. However, the security costs alone needed to resist drug violence and other social and economic dislocations carry a cost and penalty of much more than $1B annually. Colombia's GNP exceeds US$40B. Australia is cooperating with the Colombian Government in its war against the drug trade.)

In Mexico City, the largest city in the world (18m), the volume of prosperity appears greater than anywhere else in Latin America with Sao Paulo perhaps as an exception. However, a large proportion of the city's population are very poor as are the village people generally in rural areas throughout the whole country. We were impressed with the relative prosperity of Mexican business and banking interests, especially in the last four years of increasing investment and the last two years of economic reform that has strengthened Mexico as a market economy and one poised to enter the North America Free Trade Agreement with the USA and Canada. President Salinas himself has been the driving force in these recent successes. We met the President of the Business Coordinating Council of Mexico, Lic. Rolanda Vega and his Council colleagues and secretariat officers. They gave us a comprehensive briefing about Mexican business prospects including the importance of wharf and shipping reform (currently, for cost and security reasons, Houston in Texas is Mexico's largest port!) Future prospects for Australian coal and uranium are good and there are wide-open opportunities for Australian trade and joint venture enterprises. Mexico is looking to build stronger economic relations with Australia and through Australia to Asia. Mexico is this year opening embassies in New Zealand and in South East Asia. Also the Banamex bank is opening a branch in Sydney in October 1991. We called at Banamex Headquarters in a splendidly restored colonial building where this very significant private bank has been at the heart of Mexican commerce for more than a century. At several receptions we met other Mexican businessmen and lawyers. In addition we discussed NAFTA and the protection of Australia's free trade access with both the USA Ambassador, H E John Negroponte and Canadian acting Ambassador David Adam. With the Cuban Ambassador we discussed Cuba's interest to gain Australian CSIRO expertise and training about sugar production : sugar is the principal export of Cuba.
4 Cultural activities

In Buenos Aires, I was struck by the superb European architecture which flourished a century ago-the period which continued until about 1930 as the Argentine's years of flourishing prosperity. I am glad Peron was unable to demolish the French Embassy which stands today in a small region of splendid buildings at the end of the broad 9 July Avenue. Secondly, I was impressed by the relaxed ambience of Alvear Park and the nearby historic cemetery. In the park beside the pavement restaurant tables and enormous spreading fig trees were lawns on which pet dogs paraded. One pet-handler I saw was walking a dozen dogs of all shapes and sizes all on their individual leads and, in addition, slung on his hip was a monkey. Thirdly, the Congress is a splendid focal building of European style and Washington structure with fully Argentine historical artworks and historical meaning. Finally, the antique shops would equally grace London, Paris or Rome with a wide variety of expensive and elegant turn-of-the century items.

In Uruguay, the architecture that we saw falls into four flourishing periods: (1) the eighteen century Portuguese and Spanish port fortifications at Colonia on the Rio de la Plata, (2) the late nineteenth century buildings of Montevideo, especially the quite unique and splendid Congress building with its luxuriant chambers and eyecatching super-edifice of portals and statuary, (3) the 1950's attractive estancias with spanish home, thatched roofs, large practical agricultural and dairy buildings, stylish wrought-iron gateways and grids, and park style avenues and wooded dams, and (4) the 1980's international jet-set city and summer resort of Punte Del Este with its Atlantic and River Plate coasts, high rise apartments, millionaire suburban residences, restaurants and sporting facilities. At Colonia we were especially interested to see for ourselves the memorial to Captain Arthur Philip, first Governor of New South Wales, who had for about ten years prior to 1778 served as an officer in the Portuguese garrison at Colonia.

In Chile, our visit was confined to Santiago, Valparaiso and Vina del Mar. The Plaza de Armas or central park of the capital city is the historic centre of the original fortified settlement established 450 years ago. This Plaza is alive with people selling and singing and preaching, sitting in the sunshine or visiting the Cathedral on one side or the City Hall on the other. A service was in progress in the Cathedral church when we attended and nearby the Mayor of Santiago, Sr Jaime Ravinet, welcomed us to a splendid luncheon in elegant rooms. We also visited the PreColumban Museum.

In Lima again we visited the Plaza de Armas with exemplary colonial edifices, notably the Cathedral and the stately Presidential Palace. The old part of the city retains many wonderful buildings of the Spanish ascendancy when Lima was the capital of the whole continent-buildings such as Palacio de Torre Tagle and the Church San Francisco. Secondly, we visited the Miraflores, commercial and embassy area before going on to the century-old centre of art and affluence, Barranco. We dined here at the Manas Negros restaurant with an exclusively Peruvian menu and where a very popular rhythm singer, a lively mestizo woman, and combo band enthralled a packed house. However, the unforgettable experience for us was our visit to the National Museum of Peru which admirably displays the many pre-Columban cultures the most recent of which was the Inca civilisation centred in the Andean mountains near Cuzco. This very instructive museum whet our appetites to return to Macha Picchu, the Nazca Lines and to Lake Titicaca.

In Caracas we saw the city to which the poetic memories of the hero Bolivar were with most affection directed. Our own experience however was of a highrise congested city squeezed into a valley between high mountain ranges, thirty miles from the Caribbean coast. We heard commending stories about the coral reefs and beautiful beaches of some islands in the east towards Trinidad and Tobago.

In Bogota we attended a welcoming luncheon at the University of Bogota hosted by the Chancellor, Dr Juan Hernandez Saenz, Vice Chancellor Dr Evaristo Obregon Garces and Councillors. The University is one of nine in the city. It specialises in marine biology, agriculture, marketing and management, and international relations. Requests were made for Australian exchanges at the postgraduate and staff levels in these areas. We also visited the well equipped Luis Angel Arrango Library, the Religious Art Museum the Colonial Art Museum, with its magnificent emerald bejewelled crucifixes, and the exquisite Gold Museum with an invaluable array of original preHispanic gold and gold-copper artefacts.

In Cartagena we ``discovered'' the best preserved and historically most strategic colonial naval fortifications in all Latin America. The old city retains its city wall completely surrounding an unspoiled array of spanish colonial buildings, plazas and streets as they have been for three hundred years. The old multistoried and balconied villas are being restored with modern lighting, swimming pools in indoor courtyards and unusually structured rooms repolished to their former glory. At the mouth of the Cartagena bay, Boca-Chica, the cannon emplacements, chain barrier and other fortifications are well preserved from the era when they were designed to keep out marauding English seamen like Drake and Raleigh. Of course, Cartagena with its tropical beaches, first class hotels, discotheques and shops is a tourist and holiday paradise. Also, in contrast with Bogota, we needed no security precautions at Cartagena, armed or otherwise.

In Mexico, we visited the central park and the vantage point to view the city from Emperor Maximillian's lofty palace balustrades. Also in this park is the magnificent Museum of Anthropology, surely one of the half dozen most valuable museums anywhere in the world. Exhibited there are the treasures of some scores of civilisations which flourished in MesoAmerica over the last four thousand years. The last inheritor of all these cultures was the Aztec which flourished in the several centuries preceding the Spanish conquest. Cortes' victory in 1521 over Tlateloco however is not seen as a ``defeat'' of the preceding cultures. Rather, Mexicans today describe the MesoAmerican-Spanish marriage of cultures as a positive merger which needs to be appreciated to understand contemporary Mexican sovereignty and self-awareness. This fall of Tlateloco ``was neither a triumph nor a defeat. It was the painful birth of the Mestizo People which is Mexico today.'' So stands the inscription today in the midst of the Aztec ruins, the active Cathedral church and the political memories of the student martyrs of 1968. The Museum was superbly illuminated for us by our guide, Dr Cosafino Cabrera. Also she guided us in our visit to the murals of the Presidential Palace and in the nearby Museum of Templo Mayor. I am still excited by the man-sized clay statues from the House of the Eagle-Knights. The MesoAmerican cultures are another world still to be discovered by most Australians. Australian tourist visits to Mexico currently stand at about 1000 per annum but the level could well be twenty times that number. Mexico City's special treasure in my mind is the Museum of Anthropology and the cultural heritage it represents. That this culture is very much alive and being extended in contemporary Mexican art is illustrated for me by my long conversation with Mexico's Attorney General, Ignacio Morales Lechuga. In addition to the Museum we were able to visit the Pyramids of Tenochtitlan, fifty kilometres north of the city, a large complex in a broad rural valley. We also visited the Buenavista Handicrafts Market which in retail terms is very well managed.
5 Other activities of interest

In Buenos Aires, we were guided one evening by the Australian journalist, Mr Stuart Heather, contracted to ABC Radio and actively evaluating contemporary developments in South America. We enjoyed a walk to a popular Mall near the memorial marking the four hundredth anniversary of the foundation of Buenos Aires in 1536. In the mall we found a happily crowded restaurant specialising in BBQ Argentine steaks.

In Montevideo I pondered the enormous statue of Artigas mounted on his horse which stands in the central square, the Victoria Plaza. Also we visited the dozen antiques shops nearby. I was struck in all the cities of Uruguay that about a quarter of all the cars on the roads were from the 1920's and 1930's-all makes and models restored and actually used for practical transport. It was also interesting to visit near Colonia an abandoned bullring made of steel and brick, resembling Eiffel Tower engineering, but which was only used for two years about 1911 before bullfighting was banned as it still is in the south of the continent.

At Valparaiso we saw the naval and merchant ships of Chile in the harbour there and contemplated that ninety years ago, before the Panama canal was built, one third of all ships departing Australia indicated they were Valparaiso-bound. Before setting out from Australia I was determined to touch the water of the Pacific on the Chile side of this ocean that joins our continents together. I did so at an adjacent beach in the seaside resort of Vino del Mar.

The Andes Mountains may be a theoretical concept until physically seen. As it happened for us, our aircraft took the South Pole route and so we first saw the South American continent near its southern tip. For several hours we flew along the Andes mountain chain, enormous mountains covered in snow and which present an almost impenetrable barrier between the western and eastern sides of the continent, between Chile and Argentina.

In Lima there are two groups of political terrorists, the larger being a Maoist or Khmer Rouge style group intent on guerrilla violence in some rural localities and assassination and theft to disrupt order in the cities. Accordingly, all buildings, offices, factories and strategic infrastructure have permanent armed guards. For the entire length of our visit, both day and night, we were escorted by armed guards. In moving about there were ten altogether, two outriders on motorbikes, a preceding car of four uniformed army personnel toting revolvers and a machine-gun out of the car windows, and a following car with four plain-clothes armed police. We felt safe. Actually the passers by seemed to accept our cavalcade as quite normal and these security measures did not impede or intrude upon our busy agenda of meetings. Also, in Lima we observed that half of all the cars were Volkswagon beetles-there is an assembly plant in Peru and clearly it has been flourishing. They seem all to be the 1960's style model. Beetle taxis have the front passenger seat removed and only carry two passengers.

In Venezuela we flew one Saturday to the Leoni Dam at Guri beyond the Orinocco River and near to Puerto Ordaz. We were flying in a two- pilot chartered King 200 aircraft. On our return towards Caracas we could see storm clouds around the mountains. The plane diverted to the coast to land at the large international airport. Flying low over the Caribbean Sea we saw a Lufthansa jumbo jet a kilometre away begin its descent to land. Our aircraft turned to follow the jet as the next in line. Suddenly and without warning our aircraft fell sharply as we hit the wake of the jet. With great force two of us hit our heads on the cabin roof. I did especially as without any seatbelt I was kneeling at the shoulders of the pilots watching the other air traffic and the Caribbean coast. The mild concussion lasted a day and the abrasion lasted a week. The moral of the story is to wear a hat when flying over the Caribbean!

In Bogota we passed an eye clinic surrounded by four international hotels. The hotels are for patients of the clinic who come to have unique operations. The skilled Colombian doctors adjust the patients' eyeballs to remove short-sightedness, long-sightedness or astigmatism in typically half-hour procedures under local anaesthetic. Even an Australian woman has flown to Colombia for this operation. Also, on the streets of Bogota outside the Agriculture Ministry where the pavement is unusually broad there were a dozen or twenty men standing around with little white bags. We were told this was the main international emerald market-about 80% of the world emerald production is in Colombia. In the city and suburbs we were impressed by large groups of schoolchildren coming and going from school in a variety of neat colourful uniforms. Also in the library hundreds of secondary students seemed diligent and industrious aided by computer files and hands-on books maps and documents. The Liberal Party in Government has made Education a priority-this is an investment for the future which will assist Colombia to excel.

In Mexico City I was struck by the pivotal position Mexico has geographically in the cockpit of the Americas. In the North, having a long border shared with the USA, the majority of Mexico's trade is in this direction. In the South, Guatemala, El Salvador and the other Central American Republics look to Mexico as their biggest neighbour, and Mexico maintains strong political links with the Republics of the South American Continent. Mexico has a ``group of three'' energy agreement with Venezuela and Colombia. Mexico has recently completed a free-trade bilateral agreement with Chile which will stand alongside NAFTA. In the East, the Atlantic orientation is towards Europe, the destination of some major Mexican exports and a source of investment in Mexico. In the West, the fourth direction for Mexico, the Pacific orientation is towards Australia and Asia. Mexican leaders assured me that they wished to maintain all four relationships and that they were taking steps to see the Asia-Pacific relationship grow stronger. In particular we were assured that the terms of NAFTA would not limit Mexico's economic relations with Australia.
Conclusion

I conclude my speech by thanking all of the eminent people in all seven countries whom I have already mentioned-Presidents, Vice Presidents, Ministers, Senators and Representatives in all seven Congresses, officials, businessmen, academics, cultural guides and all the others whom we met and who received us so well.

Especially, I thank my own parliamentary colleagues, Senator Robert Hill, Opposition Foreign Affairs Spokesman and Hon. John Moore MP, former Minister for Business in the Liberal and National Government: they are excellent travelling companions.

I also wish to thank the Latin American Ambassadors in Canberra with whom I have enjoyed an increasingly active dialogue over the past twelve months and by whose own personal efforts we had such excellent arrangements in each country:
Juan Carlos Beltramino, Ambassador of Argentina
Julio Giambruno, Charge D'Affaires of Uruguay
Juan Salazar, Ambassador of Chile
Gonzalo Bedoya, Ambassador of Peru
Eduardo Morreo, Ambassador of Venezuela
Antonio Puerto, Ambassador of Colombia
Alejandro Morales, Ambassador of Mexico.

Finally, I wish to thank our diplomatically very experienced Ambassador Bob Robertson, our head of mission for Argentina and Uruguay and his wife, Isobel for their kindness and assistance in Buenos Aires and Montevideo. Also I thank Consul Marcello Scavuzzo for his friendly efforts on our behalf in Uruguay. In Chile, our Charge D'Affaires, Noel Campbell assisted us confidently and well and we were impressed by his grasp of the Spanish language and his affection for Chile. I make a special mention of our new friend, the Head of Protocol in Chile's Foreign Ministry, Ambassador Mariano Fontecilla De Santiago Concha whose enthusiasm and assistance in our visit was much appreciated.

In Peru we unfortunately received no assistance from our credentialled Ambassador and his staff who are located on the other side of the continent in Brazilia. However, the Foreign Ministry of Peru made some fine arrangements for us and, especially, we are indebted to a member of the National Parliament of Peru and my friend from earlier this year, Dip. Eduardo Calmell del Solar whose two staff members, Mr Francis Butters and Mr Luis Echeandia marvellously supported us in all the arrangements for our stay and we are very grateful to them.

We thank sincerely Ambassador Dominique De Stoop, our Ambassador in Caracas and his wife Jane for their generous hospitality: Also, the Embassy staff, Brent Knevett and Margaret Pinsent who assisted us both in Venezuela and in Colombia.

Our visit to Colombia, if not to Latin America altogether, would not have been possible without the friendship, sound advice and enthusiastic planning of Dr Antonio Puerto, first Colombian Ambassador to Australia whose term concluded in Canberra a few weeks before our visit to his homeland. We thank him for travelling with us in Bogota and Cartagena, for his and his wife Diana's evening reception for us at their home and his excellent arrangements for us everywhere. Equally we thank the Colombian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Dr Puerto's successor in Canberra, Mr Fernando Navas who often met with us and who we already count as a valued friend. He arrives in Canberra next month. We were happy to share a meal with Australia's honorary consul, Dr Dario Cardenas.

In Mexico, Ambassador Keith Baker who knows Mexico so very well was comprehensively professional and an excellent adviser and host who accompanied us in all our major engagements. We thank him, his wife, Marlee and the staff of our Embassy who assisted us so cheerfully and so very well. Also, we thank the foreign Ministry of Mexico and the Parliament for all the excellent arrangements they made for us.

Finally, I should add that my own evaluations of this very successful visit to Latin America will be incorporated in the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade current inquiry into ``Australia's Relations with the Republics of Latin America''. Our full Report and recommendations should be published towards the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the last couple of pages set out my particular thanks to a large number of people who received us in Latin America and to all those who built with us the arrangements which enabled this visit to be such a success. I particularly mention the eight Latin American ambassadors who are living here in Canberra and who represent their countries. I am delighted that two of them, the Ambassador to Chile and the Charge d'Affaires of Uruguay, are sitting in the chamber gallery this evening. I thank them, their colleagues and all those who have contributed, whose names I have listed at the conclusion of my speech.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to Question on Notice No. 567 of 20 March 1991, has the National Health and Medical Research Council and/or the Department of Community Services and Health advised the chemical manufacturer, Velsicol, to stop using propylene oxide in heptachlor and chlordane; if so, why was this advice given, when was it given and has the company implemented the advice; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The evaluation of Technical Grade Active Constituents for use in agricultural and veterinary chemical products is the responsibility of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC), which receives advice on public health matters from the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC).

The NHMRC advised AAVCC of concerns about propylene oxide in technical grade active chlordane in July 1990 and heptachlor in August 1990 and requested AAVCC to raise the matter with Velsicol. In addition, the NHMRC, in September 1990, rescheduled propylene oxide from Schedule 6 to Schedule 7 on the basis of adverse effects seen in chronic toxicity/carcinogenicity studies. The effect of this decision is to recommend to States and Territories that the use of propylene oxide be restricted to authorised or licensed persons only, for either approved research purposes or for approved industrial or manufacturing purposes.

I understand that the company has responded to the concerns of NHMRC and since late 1990, technical heptachlor entering Australia has been free of propylene oxide. Technical chlordane which is free of propylene oxide has been more difficult to achieve because of batch production methods but Velsicol has advised that, before the end of 1991, imported technical chlordane will be free of propylene oxide.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Commonwealth/State Child-Care Program: (a) how many long day care centres have been constructed; (b) how many long day care centres are in the course of construction; and (c) how many long day care centres are proposed to be constructed.

(2) As to each such centre: (a) what is the proposed location of each such centre; (b) what is the estimated and/or actual cost of construction of each such centre; (c) what is the value of the land on which each such centre is to be or has been constructed; and (d) who owns the land on which each such centre is to be or has been constructed.

(3) To what extent will the cost of construction of each such centre be paid for: (a) by the Commonwealth Government; and (b) by a State Government and is any and what formula used for determining the extent of such contributions.
(4) What surveys or other assessments have been conducted to determine the level of demand for child-care places in the vicinity of any proposed new services and what are the results thereof.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) 411 Long Day Care Centres have been constructed under Commonwealth/State cost sharing arrangements.
(b) There are 23 Long Day Centres where the site has been approved but construction has not been completed.
(c) 300 Long Day Care Centres are proposed to be constructed, subject to agreement with State Governments on cost sharing arrangements.
(2) (a) The proposed location of the 23 centres which have been approved but which are not yet completed are as follows:
Shire of Bulla Child Care Centre 35
Parish of St. Johns Child Care Centre 35
Shire of Lillydale Child Care Centre 35
City of Footscray Child Care Centre 35
City of Ballarat Child Care Centre 35
Logan College of TAFE Child Care Centre 51

(2) (b) The estimated and/or actual cost of construction of each centre is not known by the Commonwealth Government. The Commonwealth makes a standard capital grant of $4,500 per place (1988-89 prices, indexed annually) for child care centres constructed under the Commonwealth/State cost sharing arrangements for the 1988 National Child Care Strategy (NCCS) in all States and Territories except for New South Wales.

The cost sharing arrangements in New South Wales involve the State contributing all capital funds including land. Other States/Territories contribute the balance of capital funds required for land and buildings over and above the Commonwealth's standard grant.
(c) The value of the land on which each centre is constructed is not known by the Commonwealth. The provision of land is the responsibility of the State and Territory Governments.

(d) The ownership of the land for each centre is not known by the Commonwealth. Sometimes land for child care centres is owned by State Government, sometimes by local government and sometimes by the non-profit community organisations that operate the service.
(4) Under the NCCS new child care places are allocated using a needs based planning approach which involves a combination of statistical analysis, community consultations and local knowledge.

A national database provides area based statistics on the demand from the target population for each service type matched to data on the existing supply of child care places in both commercial and non- profit sectors. Areas are ranked on relative need to allow the smaller areas to be considered along with the areas requiring a large number of places.

Planning committees in each State and Territory examine and interpret the statistical information and provide qualitative and local knowledge. This consultative process includes consideration of additional information such as journey to work data, relevant research on issues such as projected population changes and the collective knowledge and experience of members of the planning committee.

When assessing high need areas planning committees also take into account the needs of special needs groups, with particular reference to access and equity issues. Planning committees recommend high need areas to the responsible Commonwealth Minister.
All approvals for NCCS places are made jointly between the Commonwealth Minister responsible for Child Care and the relevant State Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the 28,000 new child-care places to be created over a five-year period in the private sector as outlined in the August 1990 Budget: (a) how is such a number made up or constituted, and give the precise number of employer provided, commercial and any other and what types of child-care centres; and (b) what financial incentives will be offered to ensure that the figure is achieved.

(2) Since March 1990 how many child-care places have been created in the context of the Prime Minister's March 1990 commitment to create another 50,000 child-care places over the next five years, and what taxation or other expenditures have been incurred to date by the Government.
(3) What is the precise location of all commercial, employer-based and Government-funded child- care centres which have been, or are, in the process of being built, since March 1990.
(4) How many persons currently receive fee relief for: (a) employer supported; (b) commercial; (c) family day-care; and (d) any other and what type of child-care centres.
(5) What was the cost to revenue of fee relief for employer-supported child care for: (a) 1989-90; and (b) 1990-91 to date.

(6) In any and what manner and to any and what extent is it proposed that fee relief for employer- supported care will be significantly increased, as undertaken by the Prime Minister in his policy launch speech of 1990.
(7) In 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91 to date, what operating subsidies have been paid to any and what: (a) Government funded centres; (b) family day-care centres; and (c) other centres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The estimate of 28,000 new child care places is the anticipated response by the private sector (both commercial and employer sponsored) and previously unfunded non-profit organisations to fee relief initiatives and tax concessions announced in March 1990. The places have not been split between these categories of service providers. All 28,000 places will be in long day care centres.

(b) Fee relief was extended to families using approved commercial and employer sponsored and other previously unfunded centres from 1 January 1991. Exemption from fringe benefits tax for employers making payments to reserve child care places in centres was extended to commercial and employer sponsored centres as of 1 January 1991. Employers may claim many expenses incurred in providing child care for employees' children as deductions against assessable income including most operating costs of running a child care centre. Employers and private operators are also able to write off, for taxation purposes, the capital cost of constructing a centre. It is anticipated that these measures will act as an incentive to ensure that the target is achieved.

(2) None. The commitment to provide 50,000 additional places under the 1990 extension of the National Child Care Strategy (NCCS) is subject to cost-sharing agreements with each State Government. Negotiations with the States have commenced but, to date, no agreement has been finalised, therefore, no expenditure has been incurred. There will be no taxation revenue foregone in respect of any of these 50,000 places.

By 30 June 1991, this number had increased to 1030 centres. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: On what occasions and where has the Minister met with homeless youth, how many did he meet and for how long.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 18 March, 1991 I met with a group of young people at the Come-In Youth Rescue Centre in Sydney. There were approximately 25 young people in that group. We talked for ninety minutes.
After this meeting I then spent one hour talking to nine youth workers and counsellors from the inner city area of Sydney.
On 21 March, 1991 I went to Melbourne and spent one afternoon with the Brotherhood of St Laurence visiting homeless and disadvantaged youth at three different locations.
At the Brotherhood's Employment Action Centre in Fitzroy I met five young people for one hour. This was a representative group of young homeless people brought together by the Brotherhood.
The next meeting was with six residents of a refuge run by the Melbourne City Mission. I spoke to them for 45 minutes.
The final meeting that afternoon was with a group of around fourteen young students from the `Students At Risk' Program at the Archdoc Windsor School, Melbourne. The meeting lasted 90 minutes.
